claim: Video shows Vice President Kamala Harris “hammered.”
summary: Let’s break that down." Let’s break that down. The video clip in the Instagram post is about 5 seconds longer than the length of Harris’ actual remarks.

claim: Travis Kelce endorsed Kamala Harris.
summary: We searched Google and the Nexis news database and found no credible news reports about Kelce endorsing Harris as of Sept. 24. "Breaking: Travis Kelce Follows Taylor Swift’s Footsteps, Supports Harris: ‘Taylor Made the Right Decision,’" a Threads screenshot of a Sept. 15 X post reads. We rate the claim that Travis Kelce endorsed Kamala Harris in mid-September False.

claim: "Profesores de la Universidad de Howard confirman: 'Kamala fue la peor estudiante de la historia'".
summary: Una búsqueda inversa de imágenes muestra que el hombre de la publicación en Facebook es Bradford Grant, profesor de arquitectura de la Universidad de Howard. Hace más de 30 años que la vicepresidenta Kamala Harris se graduó de la Universidad de Howard de Washington, D.C., y una escuela de leyes de California. Harris también se graduó en 1989 de la Facultad de Derecho de la Universidad de California Hastings, ahora conocida como Facultad de Derecho de la Universidad de California, San Francisco o UC Law SF.

claim: Video shows Vice President Kamala Harris using a teleprompter.
summary: The post included a video clip without sound that showed Winfrey from behind and Harris in profile as words on a teleprompter scrolled in their foreground. We rate claims this video shows Harris using a teleprompter False. "Apparently Kamala Harris had a freaking TELEPROMPTER during her ‘interview’ with Oprah.

claim: “Sam Brown publicly supported forcing massive cuts to Social Security and Medicare and was caught on tape saying he admires the plan to phase out Social Security and Medicare in five years.”
summary: Rosen said, "Sam Brown publicly supported forcing massive cuts to Social Security and Medicare and was caught on tape saying he admires the plan to phase out Social Security and Medicare in five years." Sam Brown publicly supported forcing massive cuts to Social Security and Medicare and was caught on tape saying he admires the plan to phase out Social Security and Medicare in five years." Balancing the federal budget is not as simple as it sounds and the balanced budget plan Brown supported would almost guarantee cuts to Social Security and Medicare.

claim: Tim Walz said "we can't afford four more years" of Kamala Harris.
summary: We rate the claim that Walz said we can’t afford four more years of Harris False. She is the ‘this.’"  It included a video clip of Walz saying, "We can’t afford four more years of this." "In a stunning move, Tim Walz makes the case for Trump: ‘We can't afford four more years of this,’" the conservative podcaster and commentator Benny Johnson posted on X.

claim: “The last union member on a national ticket (was) Ronald Reagan.”
summary: Walz said that, before himself, "the last union member on a national ticket (was) Ronald Reagan." He repeated this claim more recently, in a Sept. 21 appearance in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, when he said that "the last union member on a national ticket (was) Ronald Reagan." There’s one problem with the talking point: A card-carrying union member named Donald Trump was on the ballot more recently, in both 2016 and 2020.

claim: Photo shows a toilet after “some Hezbollah operative blew up.”
summary: After pagers used by members of the militant group Hezbollah exploded Sept. 17 in Lebanon and Syria, killing more than 30 people and injuring thousands more, an image of a damaged and charred toilet started to spread on social media. We rate claims this photo shows a toilet destroyed after a member of Hezbollah "blew up" False. But the toilet image is old, and from Hong Kong.

claim: “The Montana Secretary of State left Kamala Harris off the ballot.”
summary: "The Secretary of State notified county election officials that they were troubleshooting missing choices in races in the electronic system for UOCAVA (Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act) voters on Friday morning and were temporarily taking the system offline," Aldrich said. Registered overseas voters are sent physical absentee ballots in the mail 45 days before the election, but also can use the Electronic Absentee System to print a ballot and mail it back or fill in an online ballot, the secretary of state’s website says. Physical absentee ballots for Montana voters who are not overseas will be mailed Oct. 11.

claim: “A staffer reveals that Kamala Harris doesn’t actually own a gun.”
summary: The exchange in the video was significantly sped up and captions appearing Elrod as she speaks reads: "She doesn’t own a firearm." The original footage of this exchange makes clear that Elrod doesn’t say "she doesn’t own a firearm." We rate claims a staffer said Harris doesn’t own a gun Pants on Fire!

claim: When Haitians go to school in Springfield, Ohio, they “take the place of our children in school” and “each one will have a private interpreter."
summary: Springfield schools have hired staff to teach Haitian students and other English language learners, but we found no evidence that each student "will have a private interpreter." Trump said when Haitians go to school in Springfield they "take the place of our children in school" and "each one will have a private interpreter." A school official told the Springfield News-Sun in 2023 that English language learners do not take away from the English language students.

claim: In Springfield, Ohio, “murders are up by 81%.”
summary: Longer-term data, from 2013 to 2022, reported by the Springfield police to the FBI, shows that the number of homicides has fluctuated in Springfield without a clear trend. For example, the Springfield News-Sun reported that there were nine homicides in 2021; WHIO-TV said there were 12 homicides in 2021. Data reported to the Ohio Incident Based Reporting System showed that from 2021 to 2023, murders in Springfield rose from five to nine — an 80% increase.

claim: “400,000 workers are now in a union that were not in a union when (Biden) became president.”
summary: Su said, "Four hundred thousand workers are now in a union that were not in a union when (Biden) became president." During a press conference, she said, "Four hundred thousand workers are now in a union that were not in a union when (Biden) became president." During the last 10 years, union membership was at its highest in 2017 at 14,744,00 — some 300,000 union members more than now.

claim: “Unlike other amendments, Amendment 4 has no definitions. … Without definitions these words can mean almost anything.”
summary: An anti-Amendment 4 ad in Florida says, "Unlike other amendments, Amendment 4 has no definitions. "Unlike other amendments, Amendment 4 has no definitions," the narrator said. "Unlike other amendments, Amendment 4 has no definitions," the narrator said in a Vote No on 4 ad that aired during the Sept. 10 presidential debate.

claim: Sen. JD Vance admitted he has a ‘rent-a-dog’ from the Trump campaign to make him “seem like a dog person.”
summary: The video shows Vance telling Carlson, "He’s actually a rent-a-dog that was given to me by the campaign to make me seem like I’m a dog fan." Vance did not call his dog a "rent-a-dog." Vance said his family has had Atlas since he was a puppy.

claim: First lady Jill Biden led a Cabinet meeting for President Joe Biden and her signature appears on presidential stationery.
summary: In an email announcing her Sept. 20 schedule, the White House said, "At 11:30 AM, First Lady Jill Biden will join at the top of President Biden’s Cabinet meeting to provide an update on the progress of the White House Initiative on Women’s Health Research." The White House said first lady Jill Biden and the White House Gender Policy Council would lead its Initiative on Women’s Health Research in November 2023. It was Jill Biden’s first Cabinet appearance since Joe Biden took office.

claim: Video claims to show Donald Trump in an interview with Diddy
summary: We rate the claim that this video shows Trump and Combs in conversation Pants on Fire! Now, a viral video claims to show Combs in a one-on-one interview with former President Donald Trump. This video does not depict a real conversation between Trump and Combs.

claim: “iPhones exploding in Lebanon blowing up random people.”
summary: "iPhones exploding in Lebanon blowing up random people," said an X post accompanied by what looks like an exploded iPhone. But the image of the damaged iPhone is not from the Lebanon attacks. We rate the claim "iPhones exploding in Lebanon blowing up random people," False.

claim: “Attorney General Merrick Garland just vetoed charging Ryan Routh with attempted assassination” of Donald Trump.
summary: The TikTok video’s claim that Garland vetoed an attempted assassination charge against Routh ignores that Garland said the federal investigation of the incident continues. "So, Attorney General Merrick Garland just vetoed charging Ryan Routh with attempted assassination," a man said in a Sept. 18 TikTok video that had nearly 200,000 likes by Sept. 20. But the TikTok videos ignore that the Justice Department said its federal investigation continues, and that more serious charges may come.

claim: "Taylor Swift unexpectedly lost a $125 million brand contract after a massive advertising campaign” endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris.
summary: But PolitiFact found no credible news stories in the Nexis database or public statements by Swift saying she lost millions of dollars in a brand contract for supporting Harris. "Hot News: Taylor Swift unexpectedly lost a $125 million brand contract after a massive advertising campaign," the post said. The Facebook post’s image of Swift is from a 2020 documentary about the making of her album "Folklore."

claim: “Portugal lanza monedas de 7 euros para honrar al legendario futbolista Cristiano Ronaldo”.
summary: Las dos monedas conmemorativas en circulación son una de los 50 años del 25 de abril de 1974, la Revolución de los Claveles, que acabó con 48 años de dictadura en el país. Y otra de la participación de Portugal en los Juegos Olímpicos de París. Siwei Lyu, profesor de la universidad de Buffalo, dijo que las imágenes presentan muestras de inteligencia artificial.

claim: Former President Donald Trump “started out with $400 million on a silver platter and then filed for bankruptcy six times.”
summary: A comprehensive New York Times review of the Trump family finances in 2018 found that Donald Trump received $413 million from Fred Trump or his estate over the course of his lifetime. When Fred Trump brought Donald Trump into the family business following his college graduation as vice president of multiple subsidiaries, the elder Trump "telegraphed what had become painfully obvious to his family and employees: He did not consider his eldest son, Fred Trump Jr., a viable heir apparent." Fred Trump set up ground leases for two of his developments in Brooklyn, the first of which became active when Donald Trump was 3 years old, the Times reported.

claim: Ryan Routh's Instagram bio says he is a "proud LGBTQ+ member"
summary: Although much news coverage of Routh included coverage of his posts on X, detailed news reports from several major news outlets do not mention an Instagram account or any connection to the LGBTQ+ community. Routh’s social media accounts on Facebook and X  nor his self-published book mentioned LGBTQ+ identity. Immediately after reports surfaced Routh as the possible suspect, PolitiFact reporters searched for social media accounts under his name and found only a Facebook and X account.

claim: “Chiefs' Coach Andy Reid criticizes Taylor Swift: ‘You’re not a good role model.’”
summary: "Chiefs coach Andy Reid confronts Taylor Swift ‘You’re not a good role model,’" said a July 1 post on the SpaceX Fanclub Facebook account. "Chiefs' Coach Andy Reid criticizes Taylor Swift: ‘You’re not a good role model,’" a Sept. 17 Facebook post said. "I think it's great for him," Reid said.

claim: “Kansas City Chiefs CEO bans Taylor Swift from attending games, calling her the team’s ‘biggest distraction.’”
summary: In August, Bloomberg News reported that Hunt said Swift had helped to boost the Chiefs’ fan base by 30%. The Chiefs have issued no press releases about a Swift ban, and we found no public statements from Hunt saying as much. And this particular new claim about Swift and Chiefs CEO Clark Hunt has appeared on at least one Facebook page that notes "nothing on this page is real."

claim: Former President Donald Trump could have destroyed the Affordable Care Act, but “he chose to build upon (it)."
summary: Vance’s assertion that Trump as president took steps to build upon the Affordable Care Act and protect the health coverage of 20 million Americans is simply not supported by the record. Trump said of the Affordable Care Act, "I saved it." Meanwhile, the Trump administration expanded access to some kinds of less expensive  health coverage that isn’t compliant with Affordable Care Act rules, including short-term plans that generally have more restrictions on care and can leave consumers with surprise medical bills.

claim: “Tim Sheehy told us his health care plan: ‘We need to return health care to pure privatization.’ That would eliminate Medicare.”
summary: The Tester campaign ad said, "Tim Sheehy told us his health care plan, ‘We need to return health care to pure privatization.’ That would eliminate Medicare." A campaign Facebook ad that began running Sept. 6 said, "Tim Sheehy told us his health care plan: ‘We need to return health care to pure privatization.’ That would eliminate Medicare, increase prescription drug costs, let insurance companies deny coverage for any reason, and force rural hospitals and nursing homes to close. On his campaign website, Sheehy shares criticisms of the U.S. health care system, including the Affordable Care Act, sometimes called "Obamacare."

claim: Says Colin Kaepernick said he “will go to Russia if not properly respected in the United States.”
summary: "Colin Kaepernick says he’ll leave Russia if he doesn’t get the respect he deserves in the U.S. - This is SATIRE," said a Sept. 10 Facebook post from SpaceX Fanclub, which notes that "nothing on this page is real." We rate claims Kaepernick said he would leave the United States for Russia False. "Colin Kaepernick: ‘Will go to Russia if not respected properly in the United States,’" a Sept. 13 post said.

claim: Image shows “P Diddy with Kamala Harris.”
summary: But one Threads post mischaracterizes an image of Vice President and 2024 Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris. "Here is P Diddy with Kamala Harris," text above the image says. The person in the image isn’t Combs but talk show host Montel Williams, whom Harris once dated.

claim: “If you make less than $100,000, Trump is about to raise your taxes. Currently, you’re taxed at 10% and then 12%. He would raise that to a flat rate of 15%.”
summary: If Trump is elected and he successfully keeps the existing tax brackets in place, people making less than $100,000 will not see their income taxes increase to 15%, because the tax brackets will remain the same as they are today. Still, Trump has never said that he plans to enact the tax policy changes that Project 2025 proposes, so there’s no currently available evidence that he would pursue it. Although the Project 2025 plan doesn’t specifically recommend eliminating the standard deduction, if it were done away with along with most other tax credits, then people making up to $100,000 would end up paying a higher effective tax rate on their whole income, while people on the higher end of the first bracket would be paying lower taxes.

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris’ college professors disparaged her as their “worst student.”
summary: The Instagram post also claims to quote Harris’ Berkeley law professor, but Harris graduated law school in 1989 at what was then University of California Hastings, now called the University of California College of the Law, San Francisco, or UC Law SF — not Berkeley Law in Berkeley, California. A reverse-image search shows the photo of the man in the Facebook claim is Bradford Grant, Howard University architecture professor. The Facebook post’s language originated Sept. 10 from a satire website, Esspots.com, and was shared on that site’s Facebook account.

claim: Photo shows Kamala Harris posing beside Sean “Diddy” Combs.
summary: A Sept. 17 Facebook post shared a screenshot of an X post with this photo, which appears to show Harris at an event with Combs and another woman. But the 2001 photo doesn’t show Harris and Combs posing together. A photo circulating online claims to show a young Kamala Harris posing beside music magnate Sean "Diddy" Combs, who faces federal sex trafficking charges.

claim: “BREAKING: Police found ‘explosives’ in car near former President Donald Trump’s rally site on Long Island.”
summary: We rate the claim that police found explosives in a car near Trump’s Uniondale, New York,  rally False. However, local police said that rumors about explosives found near the rally are false. One Instagram user shared a Sept. 18 Daily Mail headline that said, "BREAKING: Police found ‘explosives’ in car near former President Donald Trump’s rally site on Long Island."

claim: Charleroi, Pennsylvania, “has grown by 2,000% due to an influx in migrants.”
summary: Town officials said 700 to 2,000 immigrants have moved there over recent years, and there has been a significant rise in the number of students who are learning English in the school district. "Take the small town of Charleroi, which has grown by 2,000% due to an influx in migrants," McCormick said in a recent post on X. McCormick said the Pennsylvania town of Charleroi has "grown by 2,000% due to an influx in migrants."

claim: "El gran respaldo de Taylor Swift" a Kamala Harris "le cuesta $125 millones en acuerdos de marca".
summary: Al hacer una búsqueda en Google del titular de la publicación traducido al inglés, encontramos un artículo publicado el 12 de septiembre con una imagen de Harris y Swift en Esspots, una página web que se describe como creadora de contenido satírico. Pero PolitiFact no encontró noticias verídicas en la base de datos Nexis o declaraciones públicas de Swift diciendo que perdió millones de dólares en acuerdos con marcas por apoyar a Harris. No sabemos si el acuerdo con CoverGirl del 2010 sigue vigente, pero tampoco encontramos comunicados de prensa o publicaciones en las redes sociales de  la empresa de cosméticos, que pertenece a la empresa Coty, que digan que  terminó alguna relación con Swift debido al respaldo a Harris.

claim: Taylor Swift “lost 17 million followers by endorsing Kamala.”
summary: "Taylor Swift loses more than 100 million followers on Instagram after Harris endorsement," a Sept. 11 post said. "Taylor Swift loses 50 million Instagram followers," a Sept. 17 Facebook post said. "Taylor Swift had 301 million Instagram followers last week, a Sept. 16 Instagram post said.

claim: Rep. Ruben Gallego’s “first act in Congress was to propose legislation to BAN the use of the term ‘illegal alien.’”
summary: The first bill Gallego proposed in Congress was the Veterans Education Tax Security Act, also known as the VETS Act. Rep. Joaquin Castro, D-Texas — not Gallego — introduced the CHANGE Act on Oct. 21, 2015, with Gallego and 107 other members co-sponsoring it. "Gallego’s first act in Congress was to propose legislation to BAN the use of the term ‘illegal alien,’" Lake wrote.

claim: Of Bernie Moreno, “Now, he’s arguing for a national abortion ban, no exceptions.”
summary: Brown’s campaign said in opposing the abortion access amendment, Moreno voted to uphold the six-week abortion ban with no exceptions for rape or incest. When he ran in Ohio’s 2022 Republican primary for Senate, Moreno said he opposed exceptions to abortion bans. In his 2024 campaign, Moreno has said he supports federal limits on abortion after 15 weeks, with exceptions.

claim: “Country Music Television (CMT) has announced a permanent boycott of Taylor Swift.”
summary: "In a move that shocked the country music community and beyond, Country Music Television (CMT) has announced a permanent boycott of Taylor Swift," a Sept. 16 Facebook post said. Singer-songwriter Taylor Swift hasn’t been banned from Country Music Television despite an old satirical post that’s regaining traction online. This Facebook post isn’t.

claim: “Disney World officially moving to Nashville.”
summary: Text below the headline said: "Breaking news, Disney World is officially moving to Nashville. We rate claims Disney World is moving to Nashville False. We found no credible news stories, press releases or other evidence that Disney World is moving.

claim: “Illegal” Haitians in Springfield, Ohio, are “reportedly killing and eating pets.”
summary: The claim about migrants eating pets is unfounded, with a city spokesperson saying there are no credible reports it’s happening. PolitiFact rated social media posts about the claim False on Sept. 9, and Trump’s debate claim Pants on Fire on Sept. 10. "Kamala Harris and Sherrod Brown are responsible for flooding Springfield, Ohio with thousands of illegal Haitians who are sucking up social services and even reportedly killing and eating pets," Moreno said in the caption of a Sept. 9 Instagram post.

claim: Karine Jean-Pierre, President Joe Biden’s press secretary, ended a press conference when a reporter asked about Donald Trump’s assassination attempt.
summary: We rate the claim that Jean-Pierre ended a press conference when a reporter asked about Donald Trump’s second assassination attempt False. News of an apparent second assassination attempt Sept. 15 on former President Donald Trump has led to a slew of misinformation online. In an Instagram reel, Fox News correspondent Peter Doocy says to Jean-Pierre, "It’s been only two days since somebody allegedly tried to kill Donald Trump again, and you’re here at the podium in the White House Briefing Room calling him a ‘threat.’ How many more assassination attempts on Donald Trump until the president and the vice president and you pick a different word to describe Trump other than ‘threat’?"

claim: An image shows Taylor Swift responding to Elon Musk's X post about giving her a child by saying she's happy to take his daughter Vivian and ‘give her all the love and respect she deserves.’
summary: PolitiFact found no evidence of a response to Musk being shared on any of Swift’s other social media accounts, including Threads, Facebook, Instagram and TikTok. No such post appears on Swift’s X account, with the most recent update, a post she shared June 22, 2024, wishing Prince William a happy birthday. The "Vivian" in the fake Swift post seemingly refers to Vivian Wilson, Musk's transgender daughter, whom the tech CEO said was dead to him after being "killed by the woke mind virus" following her transition.

claim: “In 12 states, children born alive after a failed abortion have no legal protection, and in three more states children born alive after an abortion had legal rights that governors — like Tim Walz — repealed.”
summary: Perkins said, "In 12 states, children born alive after a failed abortion have no legal protection, and in three more states children born alive after an abortion had legal rights that governors — like Tim Walz — repealed." In a Sept. 11 Facebook post, Tony Perkins, president of the anti-abortion Family Research Council, wrote, "In 12 states, children born alive after a failed abortion have no legal protection, and in three more states children born alive after an abortion had legal rights that governors — like Tim Walz — repealed." Every person who is born has protections under federal and state laws.

claim: Images show Sean Combs’ booking photos after Sept. 16 arrest.
summary: As of Sept. 17, no news outlets had yet published a booking photo of Combs following his Sept. 16 arrest, although The Associated Press shared court sketches from his Sept. 17 court appearance and images of Combs’ son leaving a Manhattan federal courthouse. We rate claims these photos were taken after Combs’ Sept. 16 arrest False. "Breaking news," a Sept. 16 Threads post said.

claim: “Kamala Harris has promised amnesty for the 10 million illegals she allowed in as border czar, making them eligible for Social Security. Studies warn this will lead to cuts in your Social Security benefits."
summary: The Center for Immigration Studies argued that providing a pathway to citizenship for the millions of immigrants who are in the U.S. illegally would harm Social Security partly because it would reverse the trend of having more beneficiaries than workers paying into the program. However, it published a 2021 report that said that providing a pathway to citizenship for the millions of immigrants who are living in the U.S. illegally would weaken Social Security’s solvency. And Harris has not announced a plan that would provide immigrants who entered the U.S. illegally under Biden a pathway to citizenship.

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris is “talking about bringing back the draft.”
summary: Even if it were to pass, however, such a provision would not bring back the draft. The provision would require women to register for the draft; it would not institute a draft. Trump said Harris is "talking about bringing back the draft."

claim: "ABC elimina a los moderadores del debate David Muir y Linsey Davis".
summary: Una búsqueda en Google y en la base de datos Nexis no mostró noticias sobre el supuesto despido de Muir y Davis por parte de ABC News. Captura de pantalla de la publicación en Facebook. El artículo también dice que Elon Musk, propietario de X y director general de Tesla, y Megyn Kelly, presentadora de un programa de entrevistas conservador, comentaron en internet sobre el despido.

claim: Este es “vídeo de una inmigrante haitiana que asesinó y se comió al gato de sus vecinos” en Springfield, Ohio.
summary: La publicación incluye imágenes de la cámara corporal de un oficial arrestando a una mujer después de que los vecinos dijeran que ella mató y se comió un gato en una zona residencial. Alexis Ferrell, de Canton, Ohio, fue arrestada el 26 de agosto por crueldad animal y alteración del orden público después de que la policía de Canton dijera que torturó, mató y se comió un gato frente a la gente de Canton. Calificamos la declaración de que una inmigrante haitiana asesinó y se comió al gato de sus vecinos en Springfield, Ohio, como Ridícula y Falsa.

claim: CDC warns a third of adults may die from dangerous bacteria in ramen noodles.
summary: The claim that the CDC warned that people are at risk of death from a deadly bacteria found in ramen noodles is not backed by evidence. We searched the FDA’s recalls, market withdrawals and safety alerts website and found nothing about ramen noodle products being recalled because of a deadly bacteria. "A deadly outbreak linked to ramen noodles has sparked global fear as multiple deaths have been reported," a Sept. 17 Instagram video said through a talking fish.

claim: “Donald Trump posted this photo of Taylor Swift saying that she was crying because she lost over $150 million worth of merchandise.”
summary: "So, Donald Trump posted this photo of Taylor Swift saying that she was crying because she lost over $150 million worth of merchandise boycotting because she endorsed Kamala Harris," a person in the video said. "Trump posts photo of Taylor Swift crying," read text in the video that also included a screenshot of an X post from an account called "Donald J. Trump News." Finally, the images of Swift used in the X post struck a nerve for some Swift fans and distressed the mother of a boy who died from cancer before his fourth birthday and inspired Swift to write a song about him.

claim: “Coca-Cola cuts ties with Taylor Swift over (Kamala) Harris endorsement.”
summary: A Sept. 16 Facebook post styled to look like a news headline said, "Coca-Cola cuts ties with Taylor Swift over Harris endorsement, ‘We don’t support her endorsement.’" (Screengrab from Facebook) Users on Instagram and Threads made similar claims. We rate the claim that "Coca-Cola cuts ties with Taylor Swift over Harris endorsement" False. The Facebook post linked to an article on an unnamed website that said this endorsement prompted Coca-Cola to end its partnership with Swift because it "clashes with the brand’s values of ‘unity and neutrality.’" But the source of this claim is a satirical Facebook page called "SpaceX Fanclub."

claim: “Taylor Swift forced to cancel Eras Tour dates following endorsement backlash.”
summary: We rate the claim that Swift was forced to cancel Eras tour dates after endorsing Harris False. We could not find any news reports about Swift canceling tour dates after her Harris endorsement. "Taylor Swift Forced to Cancel Eras Tour Dates Following Endorsement Backlash: ‘Only 2,300 Tickets Sold,’" read a Sept. 16 Facebook post.

claim: Says Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene said, “Who else thinks the downfall of America started with Barack Obama?”
summary: The verified account — "Marjorie Taylor Greene Press Release (Parody)" — posted the message about Obama on Aug. 20. The statement in the Instagram post didn’t appear on that account or Greene’s other verified account, @mtgreenee, as of Sept. 17, and we found no credible news coverage to suggest she posted the statement and then deleted it. Close readers might notice that the name in the X post — "Marjorie Taylor Greene … " — is cut off.

claim: “On (Josh) Stein’s watch, rapes in North Carolina are up 53%.”
summary: It’s difficult to know how many rapes occurred in North Carolina under Stein’s watch because not all rapes are reported and not all rape reports lead to convictions. The claim is based on a total number of rapes reported over time — data that’s flawed because law enforcement agencies expanded their definition of what qualifies as rape while Stein was in office. The group cited North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation’s data on rape reports — data that has been affected by changes to how rape allegations are documented by law enforcement agencies.

claim: The plus in LGBTQ+ includes pedophilia.
summary: Morrow said the plus in LGBTQ+ includes pedophilia. According to a guide compiled by the Human Rights Coalition, the plus sign in LGBTQ+ could include people who are: Contrary to Morrow’s post, Cruz said safety is a primary concern of Equality NC. State superintendent candidate Michele Morrow targeted her Democratic opponent, Mo Green, on social media Monday for accepting an endorsement from Equality North Carolina, a group that champions the LGBTQ+ community, which includes people who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or queer.

claim: The FBI said it would “visit” Elon Musk for writing on X, “No one is even trying to assassinate Biden/Kamala.”
summary: "Unlike his kids, we’re gonna visit him for this," read the supposed Sept. 16 FBI X post. The post in the purported screenshot didn’t appear on the FBI’s X account as of Sept. 17, and we found no evidence, such as credible news stories, that the agency posted and then deleted the supposed response to Musk. A purported screenshot of the FBI responding to Musk’s post started circulating on social media the next day.

claim: "Typically you have three to four debates in a U.S. Senate race. (Sen. Tammy Baldwin, D-Wis. has) given me one debate, almost a month after early voting has started."
summary: There’s still a way for voters to cast their ballots — voting absentee by mail — before the Oct. 18 debate. Now, let’s consider the second part of Hovde’s claim: Does the Oct. 18 debate take place "almost a month" after early voting starts in Wisconsin? Early voting is another name for in-person absentee voting, which can take place in Wisconsin from Oct. 22 through Nov. 3.

claim: The “‘Inflation Reduction Act’ increased inflation and drove prices sky high!”
summary: A Sheehy post said the Inflation Reduction Act that Tester supported "increased inflation and drove prices sky high!" It doesn’t mean that the Inflation Reduction Act caused inflation to ease. Tester voted for the Inflation Reduction Act in August 2022.

claim: “In Project 2025, you’re going to have to register with a new federal agency when you get pregnant.”
summary: The Project 2025 document does not call for a new federal agency for pregnancy registration. Walz said that Project 2025 requires women to register with a new federal agency if they get pregnant. Project 2025 would withhold federal money from states that don’t report abortion data to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

claim: "Maduro llega a Rusia para pedir ayuda armamentista ante las relaciones negativas con los países americanos".
summary: Según nuestra búsqueda de noticias, la última vez que Maduro estuvo en Rusia de visita oficial fue en septiembre de 2019. Una búsqueda de la palabra "Rusia" en la página web de prensa de Maduro no dió resultados diciendo que Maduro fue a Rusia este año. Al hacer una búsqueda de imagen inversa en Google, encontramos el video en X, publicado por la cuenta del Ministerio del Poder Popular para la Comunicación e Información de Venezuela el 4 de diciembre de 2018.

claim: Former President Donald Trump posted “0-2” Sept. 15 on Truth Social.
summary: We rate claims Trump posted "0-2" Sept. 15 on Truth Social False. He posted about the gunman on Truth Social the night of Sept. 15, thanking the Secret Service and other law enforcement officials "for the incredible job done today at Trump International in keeping me, as the 45th President of the United States, and the Republican Nominee in the upcoming Presidential Election, SAFE." An X account called "Donald J. Trump Posts From His Truth Social," which shares Truth Social posts from Trump and his team, featured all of the aforementioned posts when PolitiFact reviewed its feed Sept. 16.

claim: Ryan Routh appeared in a Blackrock commercial.
summary: "The latest Trump would be assassin — Ryan Routh ALSO appeared in a Blackrock Commercial just like Thomas Crooks," a Sept.16 X post reads. After his arrest, social media users shared a video of Routh that they say connects him to BlackRock Inc., a New York-based investment management company. The post is accompanied by a video clip of Routh in the crowd at a rally with an American flag tied around his neck.

claim: The apparent assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump on Sept. 15, 2024, was “staged.”
summary: Social media users claimed the apparent assassination attempt against Trump on Sept. 15 was "staged." Soon after U.S. Secret Service agents intervened to stop a second assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump on Sept. 15, social media users started spreading conspiracy theories about the incident, including that it was staged. In July, when a gunman opened fire on Trump during a Butler, Pennsylvania, campaign rally and a bullet grazed Trump’s ear, social media users also falsely claimed that assassination attempt was staged.

claim: “The most recent State Budget increased funding for the Department of Tourism by 98 percent.”
summary: Cowles said: "The most recent State Budget increased funding for the Department of Tourism by 98 percent." "The most recent State Budget increased funding for the Department of Tourism by 98 percent," state Sen. One Wisconsin lawmaker says funding for the state’s tourism department is up nearly 100 percent.

claim: “ABC lost $27M in ad revenue after advertisers pulled ads from the network after the way they hosted the debate" on Sept. 10.
summary: We searched using Google and the Nexis news database and found no credible reports that ABC lost advertisers or ad revenue because of its handling of the Sept. 10 presidential debate in Philadelphia. RELATED: No, ABC News did not fire presidential debate moderators David Muir and Linsey Davis RELATED: Fact-checking Kamala Harris and Donald Trump’s first 2024 presidential debate PolitiFact rated claims that ABC fired the debate moderators Pants on Fire!

claim: Photos that show lists of school names are “school shooting lists.”
summary: The list in the Facebook post featuring the Georgia schools even has a title that says "2024 Title I Schools Schoolwide (SWP) and Targeted Assisted (TA)," and the list by that name can be found on the Georgia Department of Education website. Spokespeople for the Georgia Department of Education and New Mexico Public Education Department declined to comment on the lists in the social media posts. Meghan Frick with the Georgia Department of Education referred us to law enforcement agencies including the Georgia Bureau of Investigations "given the sensitivity of the situation."

claim: A video shows a body that Israel embedded with a bomb exploding during a Palestinian funeral procession.
summary: We rate the claim that a video shows a body that Israel embedded with a bomb exploding during a Palestinian funeral procession False. A graphic video shows an explosion at a funeral procession. But the video does not show a recent Palestinian funeral.

claim: “ESPN has fired Shannon Sharpe.”
summary: USA Today Sports and other news outlets reported Sept. 12 that ESPN said Sharpe would continue to appear on the network. But ESPN told PolitiFact on Sept. 13 that Sharpe would continue to appear on the network as normally scheduled. He said he had talked to ESPN about the event and would continue to appear on the network.

claim: An image shows Travis Kelce responding to Elon Musk X post that followed Taylor Swift’s endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris.
summary: A post shared by Taylor Swift (@taylorswift) Entrepreneur Elon Musk, who supports former President Donald Trump in the presidential race, responded to Swift’s endorsement on his X platform. A Threads post shared an image that it said shows Kelce responding to a Musk X post. Like Kelce, Swift has not publicly responded to Musk’s X post.

claim: Former President Donald Trump admitted during the Sept. 10 presidential debate that he “blew up the Nord Stream pipeline.”
summary: An Instagram video said Trump admitted during the Sept. 10 presidential debate that he "blew up the Nord Stream pipeline." Alex Pfeiffer, a Trump campaign team member, also referred PolitiFact to a 2019 Atlantic Council article about Trump imposing sanctions that halted the completion of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline. The Instagram video then cut to Trump at the debate saying, "He said ‘Russia was afraid of him.’ I ended the Nord Stream 2 pipeline."

claim: Patron, Don Julio and Pink Whitney tequila recalled because they contained fecal matter.
summary: A Facebook post’s claim that Patron, Don Julio and Pink Whitney tequila products were recalled due to containing fecal matter lacks evidence. We checked the websites and social media accounts for Patron, Don Julio and Pink Whitney and found nothing about a product recall. We found multiple social media posts making the same claim on Facebook, Threads, TikTok and X.

claim: Mike Rogers supported “laws that could eliminate IVF and birth control.”
summary: Slotkin said Rogers supported "laws that could eliminate IVF and birth control." IVF could still be legal under personhood laws, but experts said the procedure would likely be more expensive and have lower success rates, and providers could exit the industry because of liability risk. All that said, the bills Rogers supported would not have banned either IVF or birth control.

claim: "Debate moderators made the false claim to Donald Trump that there is nowhere in the United States where abortion is legal up until birth."
summary: An Instagram post claiming a moderator falsely told Trump "that there is nowhere in the United States where abortion is legal up until birth" misstates what Davis said. But ABC’s fact-check of Trump on abortion was not about state restrictions on gestational age. "Last night during the ABC debate, two of the participants, otherwise known as the moderators of the debate, made the false claim to Donald Trump that there is nowhere in the United States where abortion is legal up until birth," a man said in a Sept. 11 Instagram video.

claim: ABC News fired presidential debate moderators David Muir and Linsey Davis.
summary: The Facebook post links to an article that said ABC News released a statement Sept. 11 that the network fired Muir and Davis for fact-checking Trump and asking Vice President Kamala Harris’ questions. We rate the claim that ABC News fired debate moderators Muir and Davis Pants on Fire! We searched Google and the Nexis news database and found no reports about ABC News firing Muir and Davis.

claim: Florida’s six-week abortion law has “no real exceptions. Not for her health. Not even for rape.”
summary: Florida’s abortion ban does include exceptions for the pregnant woman’s health and life, and for rape and incest up to 15 weeks of pregnancy. Yes on 4’s TV ad said Florida’s six-week abortion law has "no real exceptions. "Assessing how many people who qualify for abortion care under the exceptions are actually able to do so is difficult and the limited health exception leaves out conditions that threaten the health of a pregnant person, but do not pose a risk of substantial and irreversible physical impairment of a major bodily function," Felix said.

claim: Imagen muestra carnet del Partido Comunista de la vicepresidenta Kamala Harris.
summary: Pero, el Detector que pertenece a la división de noticias de Univision, reportó que la campaña Harris-Walz le dijo que la publicación en redes sociales de un supuesto carnet es falsa. La imagen de un carnet del Partido Comunista con la imagen de Harris fue creada en una página web y no es auténtica. La publicación en Facebook también dice que el carnet fue otorgado personalmente por el segundo secretario del Liga de la Juventud Comunista Leninista de toda la Unión (VLKSM, por sus siglas en ruso) a Harris en 1984.

claim: Proposed Nevada constitutional amendment to protect abortion rights would put “essentially no limit on access to abortion.”
summary: Brown said Nevada’s proposed constitutional amendment would place "essentially no limit on access to abortion." Brown said the ballot measure would put "essentially no limit on access to abortion." The constitutional amendment would also be harder to repeal than the existing Nevada law, Orentlicher said.

claim: Tim Sheehy “would let politicians like him ban abortion, with no exceptions for rape or to save a woman’s life, and criminalize women.”
summary: Sheehy has said he supports abortion ban exceptions for rape or to save a pregnant woman’s life. The Tester campaign’s ad says Sheehy "would let politicians like him ban abortion, with no exceptions for rape or to save a woman’s life, and criminalize women." Sheehy would let politicians like him ban abortion, with no exceptions for rape or to save a woman’s life, and criminalize women.

claim: “Elon Musk is going to expose Bill Gates soon, says ‘he’s evil.’”
summary: "Elon Musk is going to expose Bill Gates soon, says ‘he’s evil,’" read text in a Sept. 8 Threads post that showed images of Musk and Gates. "Elon Musk’s shocking claim: Bill Gates is ‘evil’— prepare for the ultimate exposé!," the post said. SpaceXMania, which claims to "bring you the freshest fake news," posted a story on its site Nov. 8 with this headline: "Breaking: Elon Musk exposes Bill Gates on X, says ‘he’s evil.’" The story was labeled "satire" and we found no evidence on Musk’s X account or elsewhere online that he called Gates "evil."

claim: “Gordon Ramsay calls Tim Walz a ‘woke creep,’ throws him out of Hell’s Kitchen.”
summary: "Gordon Ramsay calls Tim Walz a ‘woke creep,’ throws him out of Hell’s Kitchen," a Sept. 6 Facebook post said, referring to a Ramsay restaurant with seven locations across the country, including Washington, D.C. A Facebook page that posts satirical content shared the claim Sept. 4 on its account with one major caveat: it was clearly "rated satire," whereas the Sept. 6 Facebook post included no such label. This post was flagged as part of Meta’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.

claim: "ÚLTIMA HORA Río Nilo se pinta de rojo sangre".
summary: Portavoces del Servicio Nacional de Turismo de Chile y de Paricota Tours, una agencia privada de turismo en Chile, confirmaron a PolitiFact que la imagen de la publicación en Facebook mostraba la Laguna Roja. En la página del gobierno chileno Chile.travel, encontramos una imagen de la creadora de contenido Victoria Ansaldo con la misma ropa que en la imagen compartida en la publicación en Facebook. Al hacer una búsqueda de imagen inversa de la publicación en Facebook, encontramos diversas páginas sobre la Laguna Roja en Chile.

claim: Photo shows Elton John wearing a “MAGA” jacket.
summary: "Just found out Elton John has publicly supported Trump," a Sept. 7 Threads post sharing the image said. And that goes all the way up to the Supreme Court," John said. "I just thought, ‘Good on you, Donald,’" John said in the video.

claim: The Minnesota Vikings have denounced Tim Walz: “We don’t suppᴏrt his values.”
summary: We rate the claim that Minnesota Vikings denounced Walz Pants on Fire! A viral Facebook post claimed the NFL’s Minnesota Vikings distanced itself from home state Gov. "The Minnesota Vikings have denoᴜnced Tim Walz: "We don’t sᴜpport his values," a Sept. 11 Facebook post, featuring a photo of Walz, said.

claim: Immigrants get $2,000 each time they cross the border illegally.
summary: The federal government does not give migrants $2,000 every time they cross the border illegally, despite claims made by Joe Rogan on his podcast. We rate the claim that immigrants get $2,000 each time they cross the border illegally False. People who cross the border illegally a second time can also be fined and imprisoned for up to two years.

claim: Video shows tornadoes in Canada.
summary: We rate claims this video shows tornadoes in Canada False. "Tornado storm in Canada," the text over the video says. That video was shared as a mirror image of the one seen in the Canada claim.

claim: Video shows a Ku Klux Klan member at a rally for former President Donald Trump.
summary: We rate claims that this video shows a KKK member attending a Trump rally False. A Sept. 8 Instagram post sharing the video said: "This video was taken yesterday. In 2023, he shared a video labeled "satire" on the channel that showed him attending another Trump rally with the sign.

claim: Elon Musk said, “Anyone caught promoting propaganda will be suspended from X.”
summary: We rate claims Musk threatened to suspend accounts promoting propaganda False. The X post doesn’t appear on Musk’s account, and searching more broadly for the statement we found no credible news coverage that mentioned it or public statements from Musk expressing such a sentiment. A purported screenshot of such an X post from Musk has nevertheless been spreading on social media, including in a Sept. 7 Threads post.

claim: A Haitian woman was arrested in Springfield, Ohio, for eating a cat.
summary: We rate the claim that a Haitian woman was arrested in Springfield, Ohio, for eating a cat Pants on Fire! Alexis Ferrell of Canton, Ohio, was arrested Aug. 26 on animal cruelty and disorderly conduct charges after Canton police said she tortured, killed and ate a cat in front of people in Canton. Now some social media users are sharing police footage of a woman being arrested for animal cruelty as proof that Trump was right and the fact-checkers are wrong.

claim: Kamala Harris “descubierta usando unos zarcillos con audífonos inhalambricos, para que le soplaran las respuestas durante el debate contra Donald Trump”.
summary: (AP) La declaración también se hizo viral en X en inglés, donde una nota comunitaria dijo que los pendientes de Harris eran de Tiffany & Co. La nota citó el blog fundado por Susan E. Kelley, "What Kamala Wore", que dice que Harris usa un par de pendientes de perlas de los mares del Sur de la colección Tiffany HardWear "con cierta frecuencia". El blog de Kelley incluye la primera aparición de Harris el 6 de agosto con el gobernador de Minnesota Tim Walz como su compañero de fórmula en Filadelfia, como una de las ocasiones en las que Harris usó esos aretes. La candidata presidencial demócrata, la vicepresidenta Kamala Harris, y su compañero de fórmula, el gobernador de Minnesota, Tim Walz, hablan en un mitin de campaña en Filadelfia, el 6 de agosto de 2024.

claim: “Elon Musk to fund new anti-woke show featuring Tucker Carlson.”
summary: The SpaceX Fanclub post included in the comments a link to a blog post claiming the new show will be called "Truth Unleashed." "Elon Musk to fund new anti-woke show featuring Tucker Carlson: ‘We need more journalists like Tucker Carlson and less like Rachel Maddow,’" the Sept. 6 post said. The Facebook post sharing the Carlson claim does not say that it’s satire.

claim: Video shows Tim Walz “falsely claims that being gay in Nebraska is ‘illegal’"
summary: The post included a clip in which Walz said, "Think about this, when I was a kid growing up in Nebraska being gay was illegal, still technically illegal." His full statement: "Think about this, when I was a kid growing up in Nebraska, being gay was illegal, still technically illegal. We rate the claim that Walz "falsely claims that being gay in Nebraska is ‘illegal’" False.

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris wore NOVA H1 audio earrings in the Sept. 10, 2024, presidential debate.
summary: We rate the claim that Harris was wearing the NOVA H1 earphone earrings during the presidential debate Pants on Fire! The NOVA H1 earrings and the earrings Harris wore during the debate may look similar because of a pearl in both designs, but upon closer inspection, they have important differences. Kelley said on her blog that Harris wore the same earrings during the presidential debate.

claim: “As of today, there is not one member of the United States military who is in active duty in a combat zone, in any war zone around the world, for the first time this century.”
summary: There are thousands of U.S. military service members stationed in areas that are considered combat zones. But the combat zones do include areas in which U.S. service members are now deployed, she said. PolitiFact asked the Defense Department for a list of places within the designated combat zones that U.S. military service members are serving in, but we did not receive a response before publication.

claim: "Dallas County Texas (tells) election workers to (illegally) lie on registration & use a church address to register homeless people to vote!”
summary: It said state law is clear that you don’t need a home to vote, and that voters can use an address other than their residential address as a mailing address. An X post said that Dallas County election workers were telling trainees to illegally lie on voter applications and use a church address to register voters. "State law is very clear: having a home is not a requirement to be eligible to register to vote, and voters can use an address other than their residential address as a mailing address."

claim: CNN reported that the Apalachee High School shooting suspect was motivated by a “lack of trans acceptance.”
summary: The CNN article did not use this wording and by the time this Instagram post was made, CNN had clarified what the Discord account said about transgender people. CNN also reported in that article that the Discord account "expressed frustration with the acceptance of transgender people," according to a Sept. 5 archive of the CNN article page. A Sept. 7 Instagram post shared a screenshot of an X post that claimed the suspect was driven by a "lack of trans acceptance," citing CNN’s reporting.

claim: Image shows “Michelle Obama’s necklace from DNC speech” said “Mike.”
summary: The image in the post is not from the 2024 convention, where she wore navy and had her hair up. "Michelle Obama’s necklace from DNC speech goes instantly viral," read the text that appeared over an image of Obama shared in a Sept. 2 Instagram post. The image in this post was altered.

claim: "In Springfield (Ohio), they're eating the dogs, the people that came in, they're eating the cats. They're eating, they're eating the pets of the people that live there.”
summary: Springfield Mayor Rob Rue at a Sept. 10 city commission meeting reiterated that there were no credible or specific claims about Haitian immigrants stealing and eating pets. Trump said that in Springfield, Ohio, Haitian immigrants are "eating the pets of the people that live there." A city spokesperson and Springfield police said they have received no credible reports that pets are being abducted and eaten by the immigrants.

claim: Haitian immigrants are eating pets and wildlife in Springfield, Ohio.
summary: Social media posts claim that pets and wildlife in Springfield, Ohio, are being eaten by Haitian immigrants. A Springfield spokesperson said the city has received no such reports, and Springfield police told a local news outlet the department has received no reports of pets being stolen and eaten. But are the social media claims true about the immigrants eating their neighbors’ pets and dining on local waterfowl?

claim: The Hells Angels Motorcycle Club is on the way to Aurora, Colorado, to confront a Venezuelan gang.
summary: But the Aurora Police Department and the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club rebutted these rumors. On Threads, a video posted Sept. 2 showed four lines of bikers taking up two lanes, claiming it showed Hells Angels and two other motorcycle clubs — the Outlaws and the Mongols — headed  "to confront the Venezuelan Gangs for taking over the apartment complex to protect the citizens of Aurora Colorado." But the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club rebutted these rumors.

claim: Donald Trump “took away protections against discrimination for LGBTQ patients under the Affordable Care Act.”
summary: Under the Trump administration, the Department of Health and Human Services finalized a rule that removed several LGBTQ+ discrimination protections that the Obama administration had instituted. The Trump administration rolled back numerous Obama-era protections against LGBTQ+ discrimination in health care and insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act. Although regulations the Trump administration issued undid Obama-era LGBTQ+ discrimination protections in the ACA, a tangled legal landscape means the ability to enforce these anti-discrimination provisions isn’t clear.

claim: “Sen. Jacky Rosen voted to increase taxes on families making less than $75,000 a year.”
summary: A One Nation ad said Rosen "voted to increase taxes on families making less than $75,000 a year." Republican-backed groups making claims similar to the One Nation ad have relied on a 2022 Joint Committee on Taxation Inflation Reduction Act analysis that showed an increased tax burden in every bracket. One Nation has released three other ads since June, all saying Rosen voted to increase taxes on families making less than $75,000.

claim: "La nueva ley de condonación elimina $15,000 de la deuda de tarjetas de crédito para todos los estadounidenses".
summary: "La nueva ley de condonación elimina $15,000 de la deuda de tarjetas de crédito para todos los estadounidenses", dice una publicación en Facebook del 3 de septiembre. La Oficina para la Protección Financiera del Consumidor (CFPB, por sus siglas en inglés), recomienda a los consumidores a contratar a un asesor de crédito sin fines de lucro y negociar directamente con la compañía de tarjetas de crédito, antes de contratar a una compañía de alivio de deudas. No existe una "nueva ley de condonación" de deudas de tarjetas de crédito, calificamos la publicación como Falsa.

claim: “Un grupo de 32 venezolanos armados tomaron esta noche un edificio de apartamentos en Chicago”.
summary: La publicación contiene un audio en el que un operador de la policía detalla el informe de una persona que llama. Calificamos la declaración de que un grupo de 32 venezolanos armados tomaron un edificio de apartamentos en Chicago como Falsa. El departamento dijo que alguien hizo una llamada de servicio sobre venezolanos armados que estaban entrando ilegalmente a la propiedad, pero que el incidente reportado en la llamada "no fue de buena fe" o "no fue real".

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris “cast the tiebreaking votes that caused the worst inflation in American history, costing a typical American family $28,000.”
summary: Trump said Harris "cast the tiebreaking votes that caused the worst inflation in American history, costing a typical American family $28,000." However, most economists also agree that the American Rescue Plan exacerbated inflation but was not the sole cause. During a Sept. 7 rally in Mosinee, Wisconsin, Trump said that as vice president, Kamala Harris — his Democratic opponent — "cast the tiebreaking votes that caused the worst inflation in American history, costing a typical American family $28,000."

claim: Elissa Slotkin “gave your hard-earned tax money to illegal immigrants.”
summary: The bill required a person to have a Social Security number to receive the checks, and most immigrants in the country illegally do not have Social Security numbers. In most cases, people in the country illegally lack Social Security numbers, Lacarte said. The eligibility criteria required people to have Social Security numbers to receive the payments, and the vast majority of people in the country illegally do not have Social Security numbers.

claim: Video shows Democratic vice presidential candidate Tim Walz dancing to Beyoncé in a cowboy hat and crop top.
summary: A Sept. 5 Instagram video showed a man who resembled the Democratic vice presidential candidate and Minnesota governor dancing in a red cowboy hat and black leather crop top and pants. "Is it 2024 Democratic Party vice presidential candidate Tim Walz," text on the video read. We rate the claim that a video shows Walz dancing to Beyoncé in a cowboy hat and crop top False.

claim: A group of 32 armed Venezuelans took over an apartment building in Chicago.
summary: The Chicago Police Department did not confirm to PolitiFact whether the specific phone call embedded in the post was real. The Libs of TikTok account reshared the audio posted by the X account Windy City Weather and News, which posts weather information and reports from a Chicago police scanner. Libs of TikTok also shared the post on Instagram.

claim: "Kamala Harris aboga por censurar X en Estados Unidos al estilo de Brasil si es elegida presidenta en noviembre”.
summary: Twitter suspendió la cuenta de Trump el 8 de enero de 2021, después de que usara la plataforma para alentar a sus seguidores a protestar por los resultados de las elecciones de 2020 el 6 de enero de 2021. La misma regla tiene que aplicarse, que es que tiene que haber una responsabilidad que recaiga sobre estos sitios de redes sociales para que comprendan su poder. claim: Project 2025 would defund K-12 schools.
summary: Eliminating the Department of Education would phase out some, if not all, federal funding for public K-12 schools and return that responsibility to the states. For this fact-check, we wanted to know how Project 2025 would affect federal funding for public schools. In an emailed statement, Project 2025 told PolitiFact the fact that school budgets rely on federal money for only a small share of their funding means cutting the department "hardly defunds schools."

claim: “The entire family of Kamala Harris’ running mate, Tim Walz—they are all supporting Donald Trump.”
summary: Of course, anyone who watched the Democratic National Convention would know that Walz’s entire family doesn’t support Trump. "Tim Walz’s family back in Nebraska wants you to know something … " he said, sharing the image. Neither did Charles Herbster, a former Nebraska governor candidate who first posted the photo on X.  Herbster, however, didn’t claim Walz’s entire family supported Trump.

claim: “Mark Robinson skips Board of Education vote on teacher bonuses to hold campaign event.”
summary: "Mark Robinson skips Board of Education vote on teacher bonuses to hold campaign event," the headline of the press release said. The Stein campaign said Robinson "skips Board of Education vote on teacher bonuses to hold campaign event." And Robinson has attended just over half of State Board of Education meetings, according to data collected by WRAL.

claim: An image shows the social media profile of the accused suspect in the Apalachee High School shooting.
summary: We rate claims the image in this post shows the shooting suspect’s X profile False. What appears to be a screenshot of an X profile shows a person wearing what looks like a Harris hat and a shirt that says "trans" with a bio that says: "Kamala 2024 end all MAGAts" and a gun emoji. A Sept. 5 Google search showed that before the shooting even happened, the profile said: "to any lawyers, journos, cops & the CIA: this content is all fake and made up."

claim: McDonald’s “said they have no record whatsoever of Kamala Harris ever working at any of their locations.”
summary: Harris has mentioned her job at McDonald’s on the campaign trail and in other public appearances. The earliest instance PolitiFact could find of Harris talking about her McDonald’s job is from 2019, when Harris marched with striking McDonald’s workers in Las Vegas. Since launching her 2024 presidential campaign in July, Harris has highlighted her summer job at McDonald’s in campaign ads and on her personal and campaign X accounts.

claim: “BREAKING: Apalachee High School shooter has been identified as non-binary trans girl Samantha Hyde.”
summary: Authorities identified the suspect in the Apalachee High School shooting as 14-year-old Colt Gray, a student at the Winder, Georgia, school. We rate the claim that the Apalachee High School shooter was identified as "Samantha Hyde" Pants on Fire! That Jackson County sheriff’s office report, which identified Gray as male, said nothing about Gray being nonbinary or transgender.

claim: “Kamala Harris said she will shut down X if elected.”
summary: The same rule has to apply, which is that there has to be a responsibility that is placed on these social media sites to understand their power. The same rule has to apply, which is that there has to be a responsibility that is placed on these social media sites to understand their power. An Instagram user shared a video Sept. 3 of Harris speaking with the caption, "Kamala Harris says she will shut down X if elected."

claim: “In less than 48 hours the United States government is shutting down for good.”
summary: More than two days after an Instagram post claimed the U.S. government was shuttering forever, American bureaucracy endured. #WWG1WGA," said the caption of a Sept. 2 Instagram post that shared the screenshot, using a hashtag common in the QAnon conspiracy movement. Forty-eight hours after that dire premonition, the U.S. government continued functioning.

claim: Photo shows a child “saved” by Deputy Ryan Braidley in Elko County, Nevada.
summary: We rate claims this photo shows a child found in Elko County, Nevada, by Deputy Ryan Braidley False. The Elko County Sheriff’s Office confirmed to PolitiFact that no Ryan Braidley works there. "Deputy" isn’t typically a title at police departments such as Elko’s, but no Ryan Braidley works there, either.

claim: “The transgender thing is incredible... your kid goes to school and comes home a few days later with an operation. The school decides what’s going to happen with your child."
summary: Trump’s campaign cited school policies that do not require teachers to notify parents if a student is transgender, but these policies do not mean a child can be given medical care or surgical care without parental consent. We asked National Association of School Nurses President Kate King what kind of medical care school nurses may give. Schools do not provide medical care without parental consent, let alone surgery.

claim: El expresidente Donald Trump “tiene la intención de promulgar lo que, en efecto, es un impuesto nacional sobre las ventas…que elevaría los precios para las familias de clase media a casi $4,000 al año”.
summary: El Instituto Urbano-Centro de Política Fiscal de la Institución Brookings, un grupo de expertos con sede en Washington D.C., calculó que los aranceles del 10% y el 60% reducirían colectivamente los ingresos medios después de impuestos de los hogares estadounidenses en unos $1,800. Durante su discurso de aceptación el 22 de agosto en la Convención Nacional Demócrata en Chicago, Harris también dijo que Trump "tiene la intención de promulgar lo que, en efecto, es un impuesto nacional sobre las ventas — llámelo impuesto Trump — que elevaría los precios de las familias de clase media en casi $4,000 al año". Aunque los aranceles se recaudan por separado de los impuestos, la mayoría de los economistas dicen que gran parte de su impacto se traslada a los consumidores.

claim: On June 7, 2011, Kamala Harris was involved in a San Francisco hit-and-run crash that injured a woman named Alicia Brown.
summary: A viral video claimed that Harris was involved in a June 7, 2011, hit-and-run crash in San Francisco that injured a woman named Alicia Brown. San Francisco Police Department spokesperson Allison Maxie said the agency found no calls for service or other reports involving a hit-and-run or car crash in the vicinity of the intersection of Post and Jones streets on or around this date in 2011. In video clips shared Sept. 4 on X, a woman identified as "Alicia Brown" claimed Harris, the Democratic presidential nominee, drove a car that struck and injured her June 7, 2011.

claim: Photo shows Vice President Kamala Harris “in the 90s.”
summary: Claudia Jordan, a TV and radio host and a former cast member on Bravo’s "The Real Housewives of Atlanta," shared it in July 2020 on Instagram. "Kamala didn’t look bad in the 90s though," a Sept. 2 Threads post said, sharing an image of three women posing for the camera. An image recently shared on social media isn’t one of them.

claim: “There’s been a 43% increase in violent crimes since I left office.”
summary: Both the FBI data and the crime victimization survey are scheduled for release later this year. From 2020 to 2022, a period that largely overlaps with the victimization survey data Trump cited, the FBI data showed violent crime falling by about 4%, rather than rising; it ended up virtually tied with 2019’s prepandemic level. The FBI has released preliminary data for 2023, showing that violent crime dropped by 5.7% from 2022 to 2023.

claim: NFL’s Philadelphia Eagles endorsed Kamala Harris for president.
summary: Have the NFL’s Philadelphia Eagles endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris as president? Eagles spokesperson Bob Lange told PolitiFact the team’s statement referred to the Harris bus stop ads. We rate the claim that the Eagles endorsed Kamala Harris for president False.

claim: A zero-tolerance policy during the Trump administration "led to less family separation than under Kamala Harris' border policies.”
summary: The Trump administration zero-tolerance policy meant that U.S. immigration officials separated children and parents who arrived at the border together. They have generally been used to refer to the Trump administration practice of having immigration officials systematically separate children from their parents at the U.S. border to deter illegal border crossings. The terms "family separation" or "child separation" have generally described the Trump administration practice of having immigration officials separate children from their parents at the U.S. border to deter illegal crossings.

claim: “BREAKING: Illegal Aliens in San Diego, California, tried to hijack 2 school buses filled with children.”
summary: Although groups of people approached buses on two separate occasions, accounts from Jamul-Dulzura Union School District Superintendent Liz Bystedt, the San Diego County sheriff’s office and local news reports said there was no attempted hijacking. claim: “Melania Trump just filed for divorce MINUTES ago in Palm Beach.”

summary: Trump said Harris "is a communist. Asked for evidence to support Trump’s claim that Harris is communist, the Trump campaign singled out her position on price controls. When Trump calls Harris a communist, it evokes fear in Americans who fled authoritarian communist regimes.

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris was fired from McDonald’s for stealing.
summary: In the comments of its McDonald’s post, America’s Last Line of Defense linked to an article by Dunning-Kruger Times that cited a McDonald’s spokesperson who said Harris was fired for stealing "‘a substantial amount’ of chicken McNuggets." We rate the claim that Harris was fired from McDonald’s for stealing Pants on Fire! Her campaign told PolitiFact that Harris worked at a McDonald’s in Alameda, California, in the summer of 1983.
