El video completo de la primera noche de la Convención Nacional Demócrata, como se ve en las imágenes a continuación, muestra a Harris de pie aplaudiendo varias veces.

claim: The order of candidate names on North Carolina’s ballot shows a “clear attempt at voter manipulation.”
summary: There’s no evidence North Carolina’s election ballot has been manipulated. The post said the order of names listed on North Carolina’s ballot shows a "clear attempt at voter manipulation." Pundits and political strategists pay attention to the order of names on a ballot because candidates whose names are listed first tend to perform better than candidates whose names are listed further down the ballot, researchers have found.

claim: “Colin Kaepernick 'screams' as Coach Kyle Shanahan denies his return request: 'The kneeling symbol has no chance of coming back.’”
summary: "Colin Kaepernick 'SCREAMS' as Coach Kyle Shanahan denies his return request: 'The kneeling symbol has no chance of coming back,’" an Aug. 23 Facebook post said. It’s been seven years since quarterback Colin Kaepernick played for the former San Francisco 49ers — or any NFL team. The post shared an image of Shanahan at a July 29 press conference after a 49ers training camp practice in Santa Clara, California.

claim: Beyoncé and Taylor Swift announced a “big endorsement concert” and said, “No more silence, before it’s too late, our voice must be heard now!”
summary: But neither Swift nor Beyoncé had formally endorsed any candidate of Aug. 27. Swift and Beyoncé endorsed Joe Biden and Harris in 2020. "Beyoncé and Taylor Swift are about to have a BIG Endorsement Concert," an Aug. 21 Facebook post said.

claim: “Breaking: WNBA referees disqualify players under league’s new ‘no anthem kneeling’ rule.”
summary: "BREAKING: WNBA referees disqualify two players under league’s new ‘no anthem kneeling’ rule," an Aug. 22 Facebook post said. The disqualification of two WNBA players for kneeling during the anthem would draw news coverage but we found none. We rate claims that WNBA referees recently disqualified two players over a new anthem rule False.

claim: “Prices are up because these corporations are scheming to drive them up.”
summary: Barrett, of Cornell University, said evidence that corporate price markups are causing rising prices has "grown over time." There is evidence that corporate profits are rising faster than inflation. However, it also noted that food and beverage retailers’ annual profits — or the amount they make above total costs — remain high, which the report said "casts doubt on assertions that rising prices at the grocery store" are because of retailers’ rising costs.

claim: Gov. Tim Walz insulted Ann Coulter’s romantic history after she called his son “weird.”
summary: Walz did not respond to her X post. A Walz spokesperson did not immediately respond when asked whether the post was authentic. Walz has not deleted any posts since Aug. 22, according to Social Blade, a social media analytics website.

claim: Video shows helicopter “dropping millions” of mosquitoes in Massachusetts towns hit by eastern equine encephalitis virus.
summary: An Aug. 25 Instagram post tied the virus’s outbreak to a video it claimed showed a helicopter dropping mosquitoes from the sky. An Instagram post claimed millions of mosquitoes released from a helicopter could be tied to an outbreak of eastern equine encephalitis, a deadly mosquito-borne virus. A TikTok video from 2023 shows the same helicopter video seen in the Instagram post.

claim: “Kamala cast the tiebreaking vote to hire 87,000 new IRS agents to go after your tip income.”
summary: The claim that the IRS would hire 87,000 IRS agents came from a 2021 Department of Treasury report that said the IRS would use the $80 billion from the Inflation Reduction Act to hire 86,852 full-time employees by 2031. Trump said Harris "cast the tiebreaking vote to hire 87,000 new IRS agents to go after your tip income." In February 2023, the IRS proposed a new tip reporting program that would let service industry employers report tips voluntarily to help with tax compliance.

claim: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz signed a law that would “take children away from their parents if the parents don’t want to consent to sex changes.”
summary: The law enables Minnesota courts to hear custody cases and issue temporary custody orders in cases in which a parent brings a child to Minnesota to seek gender-affirming care. It amended parts of the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act to enable Minnesota courts to hear custody cases and issue temporary custody orders in cases in which a parent brings a child to Minnesota to seek gender-affirming care. The law would neither "take away" a parent’s custody rights, nor would it authorize the government to take custody of a child just because a parent objects to gender-affirming care.

claim: Donald Trump posted on Truth Social that Kamala Harris used to be a man named Kamal Aroush.
summary: A screenshot purporting to be from Trump’s Truth Social account and shared on Threads contains a photo of Harris and another digitally altered image of her supposedly as a man. We rate the claim Trump posted on Truth Social that Harris used to be a man named Kamal Aroush False. The post also includes a screenshot of an X post that says, "Do you know this man…?

claim: Food and Drug Administration approval for updated COVID-19 vaccines requires a public health emergency declaration.
summary: That’s because the COVID-19 public health emergency and the COVID-19 emergency use authorization were declared by Health and Human Services under two distinct laws. An emergency use declaration doesn’t hinge on a public health emergency declaration and it can stay in effect after a public health emergency ends, the FDA said. The claim that the FDA shouldn’t be able to approve the new COVID-19 vaccines because there is no public health emergency and that other treatments are available is False.

claim: In Wisconsin, “a legislative committee cannot release funding.”
summary: James claimed that a legislative committee cannot release funding, but his staff later said he misspoke, and meant that the Joint Finance Committee of the Legislature cannot release the PFAS trust fund because Evers has already vetoed it. Democrats say that the Joint Finance Committee could release the funding and allow the Department of Natural Resources to spend it. Evers has already vetoed the legislation meant to guide how the PFAS money is spent, meaning that if the committee were to release the funding anyway, it could cause problems.

claim: “Nike announces termination of contract with Brittney Griner after ‘strong backlash’ from online community.”
summary: Phoenix Mercury center Brittney Griner signed a deal with Nike in 2013 after she was selected as the No. As of Aug. 26, Nike was selling Griner jerseys on its website. We rate claims Nike announced it’s ending its contract with Griner False.

claim: Lowe’s CEO Marvin Ellison said on CNBC, “If conservatives do not like our values, they should take their money to Home Depot.”
summary: An Aug. 23 Threads post showed an image of a CNBC logo with this purported quote from Lowe’s CEO Marvin Ellison: "If conservatives do not like our values, they should take their money to Home Depot." (Screenshot from Threads) Ellison didn’t tell CNBC that conservatives should take their money to Home Depot. Social media users shared an image that implied the CEO of Lowe’s urged certain customers to take their business to rival Home Depot.

claim: “All students who knelt during the national anthem were rounded up and removed from scholarships” at the University of Texas.
summary: We rate claims that the University of Texas rounded up student athletes and revoked their scholarships for kneeling during the national anthem False. Rather, an undated blog post with a single paragraph claimed the University of Texas had "recently come under intense scrutiny for reportedly revoking scholarships from five athletes who knelt during the National Anthem to protest racial injustice." "KNEELING: After the University of Texas, all students who knelt during the national anthem were rounded up and REMOVED FROM SCHOLARSHIPS," an Aug. 20 Facebook post said.

claim: Kamala Harris has adopted the Nazi-rooted phrase “Strength Through Joy” as her campaign slogan.
summary: But there’s no evidence that Harris has made "strength through joy" her campaign slogan. Harris has not adopted the phrase "strength through joy" as her campaign slogan. PolitiFact searched campaign speech transcripts and news articles and found no instances of Harris using that exact phrase.

claim: Jason Aldean rejected a $500 million music collaboration with Taylor Swift.
summary: Multiple Facebook users shared an image with text that read, "Jason Aldean Refuses To Let Taylor Swift on Stage, ‘Her Music Is Bubblegum, Not Real Country Artist." We rate the claim that Aldean rejected a $500 million music collaboration with Swift False. The Facebook posts included a caption that said, "Jason Aldean Rejects $500 Million Music Collaboration With Taylor Swift, ‘Her Music Is Woke, No Thanks.’"   These posts were flagged as part of Meta’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.

claim: “Elon Musk pide la prohibición de ‘The View’, ‘prefiero caminar descalzo sobre asfalto caliente que ver The View’”.
summary: No encontramos pruebas, como noticias verídicas o declaraciones públicas de Musk o de "The View", de que Musk esté intentando prohibir el programa de televisión. ¿Qué tiene más audiencia, el programa de debate "The View" de la cadena ABC o la información falsa de que el empresario Elon Musk quiere terminar el programa? "Elon Musk pide la prohibición de ‘The View’, ‘prefiero caminar descalzo sobre el asfalto caliente que ver ‘The View’", dice una publicación en Facebook del 21 de agosto.

claim: “Mark Wahlberg y Mel Gibson invierten 500 millones de dólares para el primer estudio de producción de la industria centrado en los valores tradicionales”.
summary: Una publicación en Facebook dice que los actores Mark Wahlberg y Mel Gibson invirtieron millones de dólares en un estudio de producción con valores tradicionales. "Mark Wahlberg y Mel Gibson invierten 500 millones de dólares para el primer estudio de producción de la industria centrado en los valores tradicionales", dice la publicación del 21 de agosto. La imagen en la publicación en Facebook tiene como titular en inglés la supuesta noticia de que Wahlberg y Gibson invirtieron en un estudio.

claim: Says U.S. Sen. Tammy Baldwin "believes taxpayer dollars should be used for abortion."
summary: You have someone like Tammy Baldwin that believes taxpayer dollars should be used for abortion. Steil claimed Baldwin "believes taxpayer dollars should be used for abortion." When we asked Steil’s office for evidence, his staff noted that Baldwin voted against the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act in January 2019.

claim: Maxine Waters told her followers on X not to follow Omar Navarro because he is a “Hispanic Republican.”
summary: We rate the claim that Maxine Waters told her followers on X not to follow Omar Navarro because he is a Hispanic Republican Pants on Fire! He’s a young Hispanic Republican spreading lies on Instagram," a screenshot on Instagram purporting to be from Waters’ official social media account says. But Waters did not make an online post to discourage people from following Navarro, as social media users claimed.

claim: Jacky Rosen “said ending taxes on tips would ‘hurt working Nevada families.’”
summary: Millionaire Jacky Rosen also said ending taxes on tips would "hurt working Nevada families." Brown said Rosen said a proposal to end federal taxes on tips would "hurt working Nevada families." A Rosen campaign statement included in a June 12 NBC News report described Trump’s promise as "empty talking points," but Rosen also said she supports cutting taxes on tipped workers.

claim: Mike Rogers “left Michigan to trade on his D.C. connections, helping Chinese tech companies get access to the U.S.”
summary: In an ad, Slotkin’s campaign said Rogers was "helping Chinese companies get access to the U.S."  Rogers worked for AT&T while it was pursuing deals with Chinese phone companies to sell their devices in the U.S. Rogers worked for American tech companies that had connections to Huawei — including AT&T and Nokia. In the letter, which the Rogers campaign provided to PolitiFact, Rogers’ lawyers wrote that Rogers "has never worked for any Chinese tech companies, including ZTE and Huawei."

claim: “The Harris-Biden Administration has been caught fraudulently manipulating Job Statistics.”
summary: New Data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that the Administration PADDED THE NUMBERS with an extra 818,000 Jobs that DO NOT EXIST, AND NEVER DID." But the RNC provided no evidence to support Trump’s allegation that the administration had been "caught fraudulently manipulating job statistics." Trump said, "The Harris-Biden Administration has been caught fraudulently manipulating Job Statistics."

claim: Pallets of bricks were left all over the streets of Chicago before the Democratic National Convention.
summary: PolitiFact rated a similar claim False about pallets of bricks being found near locations of DNC-related protests. PolitiFact fact-checked those claims in 2020, finding that officials in cities across the U.S. said there was no connection between pallets of bricks and Black Lives Matter protests. The posts also say that bricks were found near Black Lives Matter protests in 2020 to incite violence.

claim: Says U.S. Sen. Tammy Baldwin “has done absolutely nothing” about the fentanyl crisis.
summary: Hovde went on to say that Baldwin was merely one in a long list of co-sponsors on a recent fentanyl bill that was introduced by a Republican lawmaker. Hovde claimed Baldwin "has done absolutely nothing" to address the fentanyl crisis in Wisconsin. Hovde’s campaign argued that on the bill that passed, Baldwin was not a major factor.

claim: Videos show Kamala Harris intoxicated.
summary: Text above the video said police officers had determined that Harris was intoxicated. The first post shared a video of Harris remaining seated on the first night of the DNC in Chicago as those around her stood and applauded. Many of the social media posts shared clips of Harris’ comments that have gone viral and said they show Harris was drunk — such as when Harris described her mother asking, "You think you just fell out of a coconut tree?"

claim: Video shows former President Donald Trump thought he was in North Carolina while he spoke in Pennsylvania.
summary: Trump suggests he is in North Carolina while he is in Pennsylvania. President Trump was obviously referring to the Front Row Joes from North Carolina in the audience, whom he recognized earlier in his speech." I don’t know, somehow — would that be OK, North Carolina?

claim: The Democratic National Convention was “nearly empty” during its first day.
summary: "The DNC is nearly empty," one person wrote Aug. 19 on Instagram Threads. "The difference between the RNC and DNC is apparent. The post was accompanied with a video of Minyon Moore, the DNC convention committee chair, and Jaime Harrison, the Democratic National Committee chair, speaking to a sparsely populated venue on the convention’s first day.

claim: “Kamala Harris wants to give $25,000 to illegal aliens to buy American homes.”
summary: The Vance campaign pointed PolitiFact to Harris’ recently announced proposal that would provide up to $25,000 for first-time homebuyers to put toward a down payment on a home. The Vance campaign argued that migrants could get Social Security numbers that might qualify them for down payment assistance. The Vance campaign said that migrants who entered the U.S. illegally under the Biden-Harris administration could, over time, qualify for Harris’ down payment assistance proposal.

claim: “PA Gov Josh Shapiro isn’t attending the DNC at all.”
summary: That’s because Shapiro has been at the convention, which started Aug. 19. "PA Gov Josh Shapiro isn’t attending the DNC at all," a screenshot of an X post shared Aug. 19 on Threads said. On Aug. 20, Shapiro took the mic during the DNC’s ceremonial roll call vote, which was broadcast and streamed live, and led the Pennsylvania delegation in submitting their votes for Harris as the Democratic nominee.

claim: Trump said “you used to be able to get cereal for 20, 30 bucks a pound.”
summary: We rate the claim that Trump said this viral quote about buying cereal in pounds False. Trump has previously talked about people using an ID for grocery purchases, but he said that in a very different context. That screenshot shows Trump speaking at an Aug. 15 press conference at his golf club in Bedminster, New Jersey.

claim: Photo shows “domestic Antifa are already gathering in Chicago, to create chaos during the Harris-Walz DNC.”
summary: And Chicago police have not said antifa is gathering in Chicago in such large numbers. When we contacted the Chicago Police Department about the X post’s claim, the agency pointed us to an Aug. 13 press conference about police efforts for the DNC. But we found no evidence from police or in on-the-scene news reports that demonstrators linked to antifa played a dominant role.

claim: “Travis Kelce kneels during national anthem fined $10 million and thrown out of the game.”
summary: "Travis Kelce kneels during national anthem fined $10 million and thrown out of the game," reads text in an image of Kelce kneeling. Kelce has kneeled during the national anthem before. The Aug. 19 post featuring the image said, "Travis Kelce took a knee during the national anthem, a move that cost him a staggering $10 million fine and an immediate ejection from the game."

claim: The American flag is missing from the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
summary: PolitiFact rated False a similar claim that American flags were missing from a 2019 Democratic debate. We rate multiple X posts claiming that the American flag is missing from the 2024 Democratic National Convention in Chicago False. Former President Donald Trump also said there were no American flags at the last in-person DNC in 2016.

claim: Former President Donald Trump “cut overtime benefits for millions of workers.”
summary: The Trump administration did not challenge the judge’s ruling and instead set its own overtime rule, which extended overtime pay to millions fewer people than Obama’s rule would have done. In 2016, the Obama administration set a rule that would have raised the salary threshold for overtime pay. The Trump Labor Department’s overtime rule became effective Jan. 1, 2020, and raised the overtime pay eligibility to salaried workers earning $35,568 per year.

claim: “Women don't even get their own restroom at the DNC convention.”
summary: (Screenshot of X post) We saw similar claims that there was "no women’s restroom on site," or that women’s bathrooms were "eliminated" from the convention altogether. A United Center map provided by the DNC shows multiple bathrooms on five of the six floors. A men’s restroom and gender-neutral restroom are near each other, and two women’s restrooms lie a short walk down the hall.

claim: Photo shows “pallets or containers of bricks have been found near locations designated for protests related to the Democratic National Convention”
summary: Second, Chicago city officials at the DNC Joint Information Center told PolitiFact on Aug. 20 that the rumors that police had found bricks near protest areas were unfounded. (Screengrab from X) In 2020, NBC News found the bricks in this picture were close to a construction site and had been there for months. First, this particular image of bricks was taken in Dallas in 2020, not in Chicago this week.

claim: Democrats dyed the “Chicago River red to celebrate abortion.”
summary: "DNC has dyed Chicago River red to celebrate abortion." "The #DNC2024CHICAGO dyed the river red to celebrate abortion." Yet another claimed that the city of Chicago had dyed the river to celebrate abortion.

claim: The World Health Organization ordered governments to prepare for “mega lockdown” because of an mpox strain.
summary: The framework encourages countries to control mpox outbreaks, advance mpox research and limit transmission between animals and people. But the WHO has made no announcements about mpox lockdowns. The full article says the WHO has ordered governments "to prepare to initiate tough new lockdowns" after declaring mpox a public health emergency.

claim: A video shows “triggered Kamala Harris walks out on Charlamagne Tha God after he exposed Joe Biden’s dementia.”
summary: The video showed McKelvey asking Harris, "Is it Joe Manchin or Joe Biden, Madam Vice President?" Is it Joe Manchin or Joe Biden?" It is Joe Biden."

claim: California law lets you “rob a store as long as it’s not more than $950” and “not get charged.” Kamala Harris “did that.”
summary: There is a $950 threshold cited in Proposition 47 between a misdemeanor or felony theft charge in the state. Trump said Harris was responsible for a California law that lets people steal with no penalties as long as the goods are valued at $950 or less. Under state law before Proposition 47, shoplifting property worth $950 or less was often a misdemeanor, but such crimes could, in some cases, also be charged as a burglary, which could be a felony, Harris’ summary said.

claim: Actor Mel Gibson told talk show host Oprah Winfrey, “You sell children!”
summary: reads a third quote alongside images of Gibson and Winfrey. reads a quote over what appears to be an image of Gibson generated by artificial intelligence. "You have no proof," reads another quote over a similar image of Winfrey.

claim: Sam Brown “said abortion should be banned without any exceptions for rape or incest.”
summary: A Rosen campaign ad said Brown "said abortion should be banned without exceptions for rape or incest." Sam Brown said in the interview that he supported exceptions to abortion bans for rape, incest and when the mother’s life is threatened. A Dec. 5, 2023, Nevada Independent article reported that Brown’s campaign said it "disavows" and had "no involvement" with the 2022 questionnaire in which Brown said he supports abortion law exceptions when the mother’s life is at risk.

claim: “The NFL will now use facial recognition at every stadium to verify the identity of everyone at the game.”
summary: An Instagram post claimed "The NFL will now use facial recognition at every stadium to verify the identity of everyone at the game." "The NFL will now use facial recognition at every stadium to verify the identity of everyone at the game," text added to an image shared Aug. 4 on Instagram read. That mischaracterizes the league’s plan to adopt a new system that will rely on facial authentication software to grant credentialed staff and other stadium workers access to secured areas of the stadium.

claim: Kamala Harris y Tim Walz se tomaron una foto con un cartel comunista.
summary: Ellos filmaron el video en una oficina de campaña de la vicepresidenta y Walz en el norte de Phoenix, según una cuenta oficial de la campaña de Harris en Arizona. Aunque no encontramos el video editado en estas páginas, los verificadores de Snopes notaron que uno de los creadores de contenido del Dilley Meme Team publicó el 10 de agosto en su cuenta en X el video editado con el nombre "Dilley Meme Team". Al hacer una búsqueda de imagen inversa, PolitiFact encontró que el video original fue publicado el 9 de agosto en X por la cuenta oficial de campaña de Harris.

claim: A 15-year-old named “Graci Mae Thompson” is missing.
summary: In two instances, PolitiFact found that the users had posted about missing children before, then changed those posts to advertise properties for sale. Facebook posts have sounded the alarm over the disappearance of a 15-year-old named Graci Mae Thompson, who has supposedly been missing since July 22. But PolitiFact found no evidence of a girl named Graci Mae Thompson who is now reported missing.

claim: Candace Owens will host an ABC morning show that will replace “The View.”
summary: We rate the claim that Candace Owens will host an ABC morning show that will replace "The View" False. ABC has not made an announcement that Owens will be headlining a talk show. "Candace Owens Signs $25 Million Deal With ABC For A Morning Show," a Facebook post says.

claim: JD Vance holds “anti-marriage-equality views.”
summary: "I don't think it's actually about gay marriage, it is not about same-sex marriage or same-sex equality," Vance said. Vance and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg contradicted each other when asked about Vance’s views of gay marriage. During an Oct. 10, 2022, televised Senate race debate between Vance and Rep. Tim Ryan, D-Ohio, Vance said he opposed the Respect for Marriage Act, then pending before Congress.

claim: El senador Rick Scott no apoya las excepciones al aborto.
summary: La campaña de Mucarsel-Powell señaló el apoyo de Scott a la ley de seis semanas de Florida, diciendo que no tenía excepciones de salud mental o excepciones por violación, incesto y trata de personas. La prohibición de las seis semanas en Florida incluye excepciones en casos de violación, incesto y trata de personas hasta las 15 semanas de embarazo, y si la salud o la vida de la embarazada están "en grave riesgo de deterioro físico sustancial e irreversible". El 13 de abril de 2023, Scott dijo en X que firmaría la prohibición del aborto de seis semanas de Florida si todavía fuera gobernador.

claim: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz signed a bill “redefining ‘sexual orientation’ to include pedophiles.”
summary: Before the bill passed, Republican state Rep. Harry Niska added language to the bill that said: "The physical or sexual attachment to children by an adult is not a protected class under this chapter." The bill amended the definition of "sexual orientation" to remove a line that said: "‘Sexual orientation’ does not include a physical or sexual attachment to children by an adult." RNC Research, an X account run by former President Donald Trump’s campaign and the Republican National Committee, posted Aug. 6 that Walz signed a bill into law "removing ‘physical or sexual attachment to children by an adult’ from (Minnesota’s) human rights law — redefining ‘sexual orientation’ to include pedophiles."

claim: Gov. Tim Walz delivered paid family leave in Minnesota but “Republicans are blocking” a Biden-Harris proposal.
summary: We found that Walz signed paid family leave into law in 2023. "Democrats favor a comprehensive bill that would cover paid family and medical leave for new parents and those needing leave for their own serious illness or to care for a seriously ill family member, while Republicans have focused on leave for new parents only," Waldfogel said. Democrats have proposed paid family leave bills akin to what Walz signed for a decade.

claim: “Bob Casey and Kamala Harris want to BAN fracking.”
summary: Harris did support a fracking ban when she ran for president in 2020. Harris said she supported a ban on fracking when she ran for president in 2020. McCormick said Casey and Harris "want to ban fracking."

claim: “We’re losing 300,000 people a year to fentanyl that comes through our border. We had it down to the lowest number and now it’s worse than it’s ever been.”
summary: Moreover, though the number of opioid deaths has risen since Trump left office, it’s incorrect to claim they were the "lowest" while he was president. Annual U.S. fentanyl deaths have increased since he left office, but Trump’s claim about 300,000 deaths has no basis in fact and is contradicted by figures his press secretary shared. Trump’s claim that fentanyl deaths were the "lowest" during his administration and are now worse than ever is also off the mark.

claim: Kamala Harris voted in favor of passing a law in 2022 to tax tips.
summary: The claim that the IRS would hire 87,000 IRS agents came from a 2021 Department of Treasury report that said the IRS would use the $80 billion from the Inflation Reduction Act to hire 86,852 full-time employees. The IRS did propose a tip reporting program in 2023 that would let service industry employers report tips voluntarily to help with tax compliance. And the IRS tip reporting program is a voluntary program that would replace existing tax compliance programs.

claim: Dr. Leo Ferreira, a cancer researcher shown in a video clip, was on the plane that crashed in Brazil on Aug. 9.
summary: A Facebook post claimed that "Dr. Leo Ferreira," a cancer researcher shown in a video clip, was on the plane that crashed Aug. 9 in Brazil. Dr. José Roberto Leonel Ferreira, a professor and radiologist with an imaging center in Brazil, died in the crash, according to news reports. The Associated Press and local news reports said Dr. José Roberto Leonel Ferreira, a recently retired doctor and professor, was among the passengers who died in the crash.

claim: Videos of media talking about Tim Walz as a "happy warrior" are proof of government propaganda legalized by Barack Obama.
summary: An Instagram post said videos of media talking about Walz as a "happy warrior" are proof of government propaganda legalized by Barack Obama. The Instagram post’s narrator referred to a law change during Obama’s administration that she said "legalized government propaganda" and led to the news outlets "repeating the same Democratic talking points." False social media posts in recent years have said the law legalized government propaganda in the U.S.

claim: Says Elon Musk posted on X, “Any harassment of Trump supporters using the term ‘weird’ will be punished.”
summary: An Aug. 7 Instagram post sharing an image of the purported X post was flagged as part of Meta’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed. The image in the Instagram post includes no such logo. "‘Weird’ is being used as a slur against Trump supporters, and it will not be tolerated on this platform," reads what looks like a July 30 X post from Musk.

claim: Photo from an Aug. 14 campaign event in Michigan shows “JD Vance couldn’t fill a small room.”
summary: Kamala’s Wins shared the photo at 12:13 p.m. About an hour later, at 1:30 p.m., Meryl Kornfield, a staff writer at The Washington Post, posted on X a photo from the Vance campaign event that showed a bigger crowd with almost every seat occupied. An X account called Kamala’s Wins shared a photo Aug. 14 from Vance’s rally that day outside Cordes Inc., a Byron Center, Michigan, trucking company. "The photo of a virtually empty Vance rally going around doesn’t accurately depict the crowd size now.

claim: Video shows Boston Red Sox player Jarren Duran getting a “MASSIVE” ovation after his two-game suspension for homophobic slur.
summary: As the X community note points out, the video opened with a clip of Tigers and Red Sox fans giving a standing ovation to Tigers star Miguel Cabrera, who was playing his final game at Fenway Park on Aug. 13, 2023. You can see several of the same fans in the TikTok video in the 2017 video below, including a woman in a red shirt and blue jacket, and a man in a Red Sox jersey standing next to a little boy in a Boston cap. "Jarren Duran returns to the lineup after a 2 game suspension to a MASSIVE ovation from Fenway Park," said sticker text on an Aug. 14 TikTok video that had more than 8,300 likes.

claim: Republican Senate candidate Dave McCormick “wants to outlaw abortions.”
summary: But he has said during the 2024 campaign and his campaign website says that he does not support a national abortion ban. Although McCormick has previously made statements that could be considered pro abortion restrictions — such as that he "believes life begins at conception" — he has said during the 2024 campaign cycle that he opposes a national abortion ban. It also says McCormick said he opposes exceptions for abortion restrictions in cases of rape and incest, a claim previous ads also have focused on.

claim: “Elon Musk has announced his first robot girlfriend, with artificial intelligence.”
summary: The image of Musk seated in a restaurant with a humanoid robot is not real. "Elon Musk has announced his first robot girlfriend, with artificial intelligence. Tech 4 Peace, an Iraqi fact-checking outlet and signatory of the International Fact-Checking Network, also reported that the image of Musk with the supposed girlfriend robot was created with artificial intelligence.

claim: “Vice President, Kamala Harris cast the tie-breaking vote to cut, as you know, Medicare by $273 billion. She cast a vote to cut Medicare.”
summary: But the government’s spending less on Medicare programs would not amount to the kind of "cut" to Medicare benefits Trump implied, experts told KFF Health News. The analysis Trump cited, per his campaign, said the Inflation Reduction Act’s health care provisions would lower the deficit by $237 billion — not $273 billion, as the former president claimed. "The idea behind drug price negotiation is that Medicare can use its buying power to get a better price than what is currently being negotiated for these drugs," said Juliette Cubanski, deputy director of the program on Medicare policy at KFF, a health information nonprofit that includes KFF Health News.

claim: Sen. Rick Scott does not support abortion exceptions.
summary: Scott has also said he prefers abortion limits at 15 weeks of pregnancy, with exceptions for rape, incest and the life of the pregnant woman, because he believes that’s what most Americans support. He has said that, if he were Florida’s governor, he would have signed the state’s current six-week abortion ban, which includes exceptions for rape and incest through 15 weeks of pregnancy and the pregnant woman’s health and life. Mucarsel-Powell said Scott does not support abortion exceptions.

claim: "Elon Musk anuncia su primera novia (un robot con inteligencia artificial)".
summary: Tech 4 Peace, un medio de verificación iraquí, signatario de la Red Internacional de Verificación de Hechos, también reportó que la imagen de Musk con la supuesta robot fue creada con inteligencia artificial. La imagen de Musk sentado en un restaurante con una robot humanoide no es real y no hay pruebas de que él anunció "su primera novia (un robot con inteligencia artificial)". El 15 de enero Musk publicó un video en X de uno de los humanoides doblando ropa.

claim: Kamala Harris posted about banning Barron Trump’s friend from X because he wore a “Biden Loves Minors” shirt.
summary: But Vice President Kamala Harris did not demand Loudon’s banning from social media for wearing a "Biden Loves Minors" shirt, as social media users have claimed. We rate the claim that Harris posted about banning Barron Trump’s friend from X because he wore a "Biden Loves Minors" shirt False. Harris has not deleted any posts on her X account in the past 30 days, data collected by Social Blade, a social media analytics website, showed.

claim: Video shows former President Donald Trump freezing up.
summary: Thank you, thank you very much, thank you. Thank you. Thank you."

claim: Video muestra policías entrando en una casa en Inglaterra "por comentarios en redes sociales".
summary: El comunicado incluye un video mostrando varias de las casas a las que entraron, la puerta en una de ellas se parece a la del video en Instagram. Fleur Armitage, una portavoz de la Policía de Gran Manchester, le dijo a PolitiFact que el video en Instagram no muestra lo que la publicación dice. El 29 de julio en la ciudad de Southport, en el noroeste de Inglaterra, tres niñas fueron apuñaladas mortalmente y cinco menores y dos adultos fueron heridos gravemente en un centro comunitario, según la policía local.

claim: “During Covid, Tim Walz rationed access to monoclonal antibody treatments based on skin color.”
summary: Minnesota later designed a scoring system first used in December 2021 that assigned people points, on a scale of zero to 25, based on categories of clinical risk from COVID-19, The program used the Mayo Clinic’s Monoclonal Antibody Screening Score, but added categories for pregnant women and Black, Indigenous and people of color as risk factors. Minnesota’s health department cited the FDA’s guidance in 2021 emergency-use approvals for monoclonal antibody treatments that "in addition to certain underlying health conditions, race and ethnicity "may also place individual patients at high risk for progression to severe COVID-19." Kirk’s claim that Minnesota rationed health care by skin color has elements of truth in that a scoring system awarded patients who were Black, Indigenous or people of color 2 points, the same as patients with diabetes or cardiovascular disease and more than a patient with hypertension.

claim: JD Vance “literally wrote the foreword for the architect of the Project 2025 agenda."
summary: Walz said Vance "literally wrote the foreword for the architect of the Project 2025 agenda." Vance wrote the forward for a book authored by Roberts, the Heritage Foundation’s president and a Project 2025 leader. Vance literally, literally wrote the foreword for the architect of the Project 2025 agenda," Walz said Aug. 6 in Philadelphia, as Vice President Kamala Harris stood behind him.

claim: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz “forced schools to stock tampons in boys’ bathrooms.”
summary: In 2023, Walz signed a law requiring schools provide access to menstrual products in bathrooms regularly used by students in grades 4 to 12, according to a plan school districts will create. For example, the law would allow a school administrator who knows there are trans or nonbinary students who only use the boys’ restrooms to provide menstrual products in those bathrooms, she said. Searching the Nexis news database, we found no reports that menstrual products are being provided currently in boys’ restrooms in any Minnesota school district.

claim: Craigslist ad shows “every single person” at Kamala Harris’ Arizona rally was paid.
summary: We rate the claim that a Craigslist ad shows "every single person" at Kamala Harris’ Arizona rally was paid False. An image of a Craigslist ad then appears with the title, "Actors needed (Phoenix Convention Center)." A Harris-Walz campaign spokesperson told PolitiFact that their "campaign does not pay people to attend rallies, including the recent rally in Arizona," adding that the event was open to the public and people could RSVP until the event reached capacity.

claim: Photo of Kamala Harris’ Aug. 7 rally near Detroit was AI-generated and “there was nobody there.” Attendees pictured “didn’t exist.”
summary: Supporters listen Aug. 7, 2024, as Democratic presidential nominee Vice President Kamala Harris speaks at a campaign rally in Romulus, Michigan. "This is an actual photo of a 15,000-person crowd for Harris-Walz in Michigan," the Harris campaign wrote in an Aug. 11 X post, sharing the contested photo. Lavora Barnes, Michigan’s Democratic Party chair, shared a photo on X of herself addressing the Aug. 7 crowd and joked about Trump’s AI-generated crowd claim.

claim: Says Tim Walz said he carried weapons in war, but “he has not spent a day in a combat zone.”
summary: But was what Vance said about Walz not carrying weapons in combat accurate? Vance said that Walz said he carried weapons in war, but "he has not spent a day in a combat zone." Vance attacked Tim Walz on military record.

claim: El gobernador de Minnesota, Tim Walz, firmó una ley dando educación universitaria gratuita “a los inmigrantes ilegales”.
summary: El segundo proyecto de ley transfirió $5 millones de ese dinero a un programa diferente de becas de matrícula universitaria para estudiantes que estuvieron en el sistema de hogares de acogida. Walz firmó dos proyectos de ley de educación superior en 2023 y 2024 que cubren los costos de matrícula en las universidades públicas de Minnesota para estudiantes cuyas familias ganan menos de $80,000 al año. Esta es la historia resumida: Walz firmó en ley un programa de becas que cubre la matrícula en las universidades públicas de Minnesota para los estudiantes que cumplan las restricciones de ingresos familiares.

claim: “I went down in a helicopter with (Willie Brown). We thought maybe this is the end. We were in a helicopter going to a certain location together and there was an emergency landing.”
summary: Former President Donald Trump’s tale of an emergency helicopter landing unraveled after one of its main characters, former San Francisco Mayor Willie Brown, told news outlets it never happened. Trump did fly on a helicopter with a different Democrat named Brown — former California Gov. Although we found no news articles about a helicopter crash or emergency landing involving Trump and Brown, we discovered a report about one treacherous helicopter trip involving the former mayor.

claim: Says Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz had his stomach pumped “after overingesting horse semen.”
summary: Although there is a West Point News in West Point, Nebraska, we didn’t find a West Point Daily News. We also found no West Point General Hospital in West Point, Nebraska, or evidence of a Dr. Amanda Thompson who worked there. The photo that appears in the purported stomach-pumping story has been used in connection with his time teaching there at Mankato West High School.

claim: Photo shows former President Donald Trump “asleep at the 2017 NATO summit.”
summary: We rate claims this photo shows Trump sleeping at the 2017 NATO summit False. "Remember that time when Trump fell asleep at the 2017 NATO summit? An old photo of former President Donald Trump, sitting with his head bowed, is being shared anew on social media and presented as evidence that he was caught sleeping at a 2017 NATO summit in Brussels, Belgium.

claim: “Mike Tyson says he’s willing to box Olympic DUDE with all proceeds to go to a battered women’s charity.”
summary: "Mike Tyson says he’s willing to box Olympic DUDE with all proceeds to go to a battered women’s charity," an Aug. 2 Threads post said, sharing side-by-side photos of Tyson Khelif. The Boxing Unit, which the International Olympic Committee set up and which handled eligibility for boxing at the 2024 Paris Olympics, affirmed Khelif could compete. But the International Olympic Committee no longer recognizes the International Boxing Association.

claim: Says his Jan. 6, 2021, speech on the White House Ellipse drew the “same number of people,” as the 1963 March on Washington where Martin Luther King Jr. gave his “I Have a Dream” speech.
summary: (AP)   The question that triggered Trump’s crowd-size answer was about Jan. 6, and Trump called it "the biggest crowd I’ve ever spoken to." Describing his speech to supporters on Jan. 6, 2021, Trump said he spoke to the "same number of people, if not, we had more" than King’s 1963 "I Have a Dream" speech. Here is an image of the crowd during King’s speech: A crowd near the Reflecting Pool listens to Martin Luther King Jr. and other speakers during the March on Washington in 1963.

claim: “Caitlin Clark declines $1 million offer from ABC to appear on ‘The View.’”
summary: "BREAKING: Caitlin Clark declines $1 million offer from ABC to appear on ‘The View,’" an Aug. 5 Facebook post said. We rate claims Clark turned down a $1 million "The View" appearance False. The Facebook post resharing the claim did not label it as satire.

claim: Image shows Hitler in similar scene as Trump.
summary: We rate the claim that this image shows Hitler in a similar scene as Trump False. Hitler survived assassination attempts but the Threads post’s image of him is altered. The original photo shares no resemblance to the image of Trump on July 13.

claim: "Tim Walz firmó una ley para dar licencia de conducir a inmigrantes ilegales en Minnesota".
summary: La ley entró en vigor el 1 de octubre de 2023. La población de Minnesota es de unos 5.7 millones de habitantes. obtener una licencia de conducir estándar o tarjeta de identificación de Minnesota.

claim: "El crimen violento aumentó bajo Donald Trump".
summary: Después de disminuir durante los primeros tres años de la presidencia de Trump, el aumento de la tasa de crímenes violentos en 2020 (su último año del republicano en el cargo) fue lo suficientemente grande como para borrar las disminuciones de los años anteriores de su mandato. Sin embargo, incluso considerando el repunte de 2020, la tasa de crímenes violentos en el último año de Trump fue aún más baja que en el último año de su predecesor, el presidente demócrata Barack Obama. La última parte de la declaración de Walz se refería a la condena de Trump en mayo de 2024 por 34 cargos de falsificación de registros comerciales en un esquema para encubrir un pago de dinero secreto a la actriz porno Stormy Daniels previo a las elecciones presidenciales de 2016.

claim: "Tim Walz signed into law driver's licenses for illegal immigrants in Minnesota."
summary: On March 7, 2023, as Minnesota governor, Walz signed H.F. 4, a bill that expanded access to driver’s licenses to people in the state, regardless of their immigration status. Walz signed a bill in 2023 expanding access to driver’s licenses regardless of immigration status in Minnesota. Tim Walz signed law giving some Minnesota students, including migrants, free in-state tuition

claim: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz signed “legislation giving free college … to illegal immigrants.”
summary: Students who are illegally in the U.S. can apply for this tuition aid if they have attended a Minnesota school for at least three years, graduated or received a GED certificate in Minnesota and satisfied other requirements for income and maintaining their school’s GPA standards. The short story: Walz signed a scholarship program into law that covers tuition at Minnesota public colleges and universities for students who meet family income restrictions. In the 2021-22 school year, 314 Minnesotan students received financial aid through the Minnesota Dream Act.

claim: “When Tim Walz was asked by his country to go to Iraq, do you know what he did? He dropped out of the Army and allowed his unit to go without him.”
summary: The Minnesota National Guard said the battalion then received an official order about mobilizing for deployment to Iraq in July 2005, after Walz retired. Walz retired from the Minnesota National Guard in May 2005. Al Bonnifield, who served with Walz in the Minnesota National Guard, told Minnesota Public Radio in 2018 that Walz weighed his retirement from the guard and congressional run "very heavy."

claim: “In 2021, Minnesotans were roughly five times more likely to move to Florida than vice versa” because they were “fleeing” the state under Democratic Gov. Tim Walz.
summary: In 2021, almost four times as many Minnesotans moved to Florida than Floridians moved to Minnesota in 2021. DeSantis’ office, pointing to U.S. Census data, said that over 2021-22, "up to five people moved to Florida from Minnesota for every person moving out of Florida to Minnesota." Stefan Rayer, director of the University of Florida’s Population Program in the Bureau of Economic and Business Research, reviewed 2021 Census data and calculated that about 10,156 people moved from Minnesota to Florida and about 2,712 from Florida to Minnesota — a net gain of 7,444 people for Florida.

claim: A plane crashed into the Milad Tower, July 31, 2024.
summary: A Facebook post shows a video of a plane seemingly crashing into a tower and exploding. PolitiFact found no credible media reports of a plane crashing into Milad Tower in 2024. On his Instagram and TikTok accounts we found the same video of the plane crashing into a tower, posted July 13.

claim: "Actornautas aparecen en los videos de la NASA desde hace años mostrando el set de filmación en el supuesto alunizaje”.
summary: Una publicación en Facebook dice que un video muestra que el primer aterrizaje a la Luna  de la NASA fue un engaño. El primer aterrizaje a la Luna si sucedió bajo la misión de Apollo 11 y el video de una supuesta actuación no es de la NASA, sino que fue creado como broma. "ACTORNAUTAS aparecen en los videos de la NASA desde hace años mostrando el set de filmación en el supuesto alunizaje", dice la publicación del 26 de mayo.

claim: In negotiating releases of Americans held abroad, “(I) gave the opposing country NOTHING — and never any cash.”
summary: In one instance, the U.S. agreed to pay money to North Korea for the release of a U.S. citizen, but a White House official said the money was never sent. However, Bolton, who was not working in the Trump administration at the time of Warmbier’s release, said the U.S. "absolutely" did not pay North Korea any money for the release. National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan said the U.S. did not exchange money in the deal.

claim: In Pompano Beach, Florida, Somali immigrants illegally in the U.S. were in line to get driver’s licenses and “all you need to vote is a driver's license.”
summary: A video shared on social media claimed to show Somali immigrants in line to get driver’s licenses in Pompano Beach, Florida, and said, "All you need to vote is a driver's license." A video shared across social media showed what it said were hundreds of Somalis illegally in the U.S. lined up to get driver’s licenses in south Florida. Florida law prohibits immigrants in the U.S. illegally from getting driver’s licenses.

claim: “Violent crime was up under Donald Trump.”
summary: But in 2020, the violent crime rate spiked to 385.2 per 100,000 people — higher than any previous year under Trump. Even accounting for the 2020 spike, the violent crime rate in Trump’s final year was still lower than it was during the final year of his predecessor, President Barack Obama. However, the violent crime rate in Trump’s final year was still slightly lower than it was during the final year of his predecessor, Obama.

claim: President Joe Biden walked “onto an empty airplane for no reason.”
summary: We rate claims that Biden boarded an empty plane for no reason False. As fact-checking website Snopes reported, a Black Star Network livestream of Biden and Harris greeting the Americans shows someone on the plane after Biden disembarks again. Biden later boarded the plane that had brought the prisoners to Maryland, setting off a chorus of claims questioning the president’s movements.

claim: “Police found human remains and evidence of cannibalism” at Oprah Winfrey’s home.
summary: More than seven months later, a screenshot of one response is being shared on other social media platforms: "That time police found human remains and evidence of cannibalism in her LA home that she sold in 2013." "why are ppl actually believing this … y’all believe anything"  We rate claims police found evidence of cannibalism and human remains at Winfrey’s home Pants on Fire! We looked for news stories, police reports and other credible sources to corroborate this claim but found none.

claim: “Michael Jordan rejects $400 million Disney offer, stating, ‘I do not collaborate with companies aligned with woke ideologies.’”
summary: "Breaking: Michael Jordan Rejects $400 Million Disney Offer, Stating ‘I Do Not Collaborate With Companies Aligned With Woke Ideologies’ In Bold Move," an Aug. 3 Facebook post said. Former NBA and "Space Jam" star Michael Jordan didn’t decry The Walt Disney Co., despite a claim bouncing around the internet. In 2023, fact-checkers checked a similar claim that Jordan had turned down a $120 million ad campaign with Disney.

claim: “Scientists at Exeter University have reconstructed this 3D model of how Moses might have looked.”
summary: In 2022, PolitIFact fact-checked a claim that Stanford University scientists published a 3D image of what Joseph of Nazareth might have looked like: a rendering of André René Roussimof, a French former professional wrestler and actor known as Andre the Giant. "Scientists at Exeter University have reconstructed this 3D model of how Moses might have looked," the July 31 post said. We found nothing on the website of the University of Exeter, in the United Kingdom, to support the claim that scientists there rendered a 3D model of Moses.

claim: During the 2020 Minnesota riots after George Floyd’s murder, Gov. Tim Walz didn’t call in the National Guard, “so, I sent in the National Guard to save Minneapolis.”
summary: Trump said that during the 2020 Minnesota riots, Walz didn’t call in the National Guard. Frey said he called Walz on the evening of May 27, 2020, asking him to send in the National Guard and Walz said he would consider it. However, Walz spokesperson Teddy Tschann wrote in a statement to CNN in 2020 that Walz "activated the Minnesota National Guard at the request of the Mayors of Minneapolis and St. Paul, before he talked to the White House."

claim: “Elon Musk calls for ban on ‘The View,’ ‘I’d rather walk barefoot on hot asphalt than watch ‘The View.’”
summary: We found no evidence, such as credible news reports or public statements from Musk or "The View," that he is seeking to ban the show from television. Now circulating on social media: purported "breaking" news that "Musk calls for ban on ‘The View’" and said, "I’d rather walk barefoot on hot asphalt than watch ‘The View.’" A July 27 Facebook post sharing the claim was flagged as part of Meta’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed. The blog describes itself as a source of "fake news stories."

claim: Kamala Harris “supports mandatory gun confiscation.”
summary: Trump said Harris "supports mandatory gun confiscation." We asked the Harris campaign whether she still supports mandatory assault weapons buybacks. While running in the 2019 presidential primary, Harris said, "I support a mandatory gun buyback program" for assault weapons.

claim: Donald Trump “intends to cut” Medicare.
summary: In his 2024 campaign, Trump has made clear that his Medicare policy is to make no cuts. As president, though, Trump regularly proposed policies that would have reduced Medicare spending. During the 2024 presidential campaign, Trump has repeatedly said he would not cut Medicare.

claim: Eric Hovde “wants to repeal the Affordable Care Act, and kick millions off their health insurance.”
summary: Baldwin said Hovde "wants to repeal the Affordable Care Act, and kick millions off their health insurance." On the health care page, Hovde doesn’t explicitly say he wants to repeal the Affordable Care Act, rather that the health care system is "deeply flawed and in need of reform." Does Hovde want to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare?

claim: Tim Walz “changed the Minnesota flag so it could resemble the Somalian flag.”
summary: He said of the new flag, "We've evolved into a more diverse state and I think it's more reflective of that," according to a May report by WCCO-TV, a CBS News affiliate.. Simon, in a December commission meeting before the final design was chosen, spoke about complaints about the flag design proposals’ resemblance to other countries’ flags; he noted that Iowa’s state flag bears a resemblance to the French flag and Texas’ state flag is similar to Chile’s. But Walz played no role in a state commission’s monthslong process to choose a new design for the state flag and logo, other than appointing three commission members. Many of those claims were based on proposed Minnesota flag designs and not on the state flag’s final design.

claim: “Elon Musk backs Caitlin Clark, offers $10 million endorsement.”
summary: "We post SATIRE, nothing on this page is real," the SpaceX Fanclub Facebook account page says. "Elon Musk backs Caitlin Clark, offers $10 million endorsement: ‘I support you, Caitlin Clark,’" a recent Facebook post said. This claim originated on a self-described satire site and corresponding Facebook account, SpaceX Fanclub.

claim: Kamala Harris’ X post said the Olympics’ opening ceremony “made France look great! America, this is what we need to strive towards!”
summary: A July 28 X post that included a screenshot of what appeared to be a Harris X post that said, "What an impressive show by all of these beautiful and diverse people at the Opening Ceremony of The Olympics! But Harris didn’t post on X with that, or anything else, reacting to the Olympics’ opening ceremony. The fabricated post shows three scenes screenshotted from the July 26 opening ceremony.

claim: Photo shows Israeli swimmers protesting Olympic rules by spelling out “bring them home.”
summary: The Israeli artistic swimming team also shared the image on Instagram that day. We rate claims this photo shows Israel’s national swimming team protesting Olympic rules False. Spiegel, who also didn’t respond to PolitiFact’s questions about the post, told Agence France-Presse that it was "a fake news story."

claim: “Nowhere on her birth certificate does it say that she is BLACK OR AFRICAN. … Kamala Harris is NOT black and never has been.”
summary: Loomer claimed a birth certificate proves Harris is not Black and never has been because it doesn’t say she is Black or African. The birth certificate does not address Kamala Harris’ race. But Harris’ birth certificate did not include information about her race.

claim: "Since Vice President Harris and I took office … incomes have risen faster than prices."
summary: This distinction matters because if Biden had said "wages" had exceeded inflation since he took office, he would have been wrong. After adjusting for inflation, per capita personal income after taxes has risen modestly, once you remove the temporary influx of pandemic-era stimulus cash that distorts the data for January 2021, Biden’s first month in office. "Since Vice President Harris and I took office, our economy has created nearly 16 million jobs, average unemployment has been lower than during any administration in 50 years, and incomes have risen faster than prices," Biden said in an Aug. 2 statement.

claim: Video shows a “strong tornado in Atlanta.”
summary: A EF2 tornado touched down in Atlanta in April — at night, in the dark — and none of the clips in the Facebook post, all recorded in daylight, show the Georgia twister. We rate claims these clips show a tornado in Atlanta False. The caption of the July 21 Facebook post sharing the video: "Strong tornado in Atlanta USA."

claim: Says Simone Biles “announces retirement” and “reveals she is ‘expecting a baby.’”
summary: Even before her final performance Aug. 5 in the Paris Games, a floor routine that netted her the silver medal, a Facebook post claimed that Biles had announced her retirement and said she was pregnant. Simone Biles is the most decorated gymnast in history and she finished the 2024 Olympics with three gold medals and one silver. "Just Reported that America’s most decorated Olympic gymnast of all time, Simone Biles Announces Retirement at 27 After Securing Gold at Paris Olympics, Reveals she is ‘expecting a baby’ with her husband, Jonathan Owens.

claim: Olympic air pistol shooting medalist took up the sport during his divorce and told his ex-wife from the podium, “I want my dog back.”
summary: Along with the jokes, one story about Dikec making the rounds on social media claims he had a dark backstory to his shooting prowess. One Facebook post shared side-by-side photos of Dikec shooting at the Olympics next to one of him at home with the cat. But the tall tale came from a satirical account called The Sportsmemery, which shared the fake Dikec story in an Aug. 1 post that it described as satire, something the other posts sharing the story omitted.

claim: "Samsung drops out of $1 billion advertising campaign with Olympics."
summary: We rate the claim that Samsung has withdrawn sponsorship for the Olympics False. "The IOC has an agreement with Worldwide Olympic Partner Samsung through 2028," the statement said. Since the opening ceremony, Samsung has continued to share articles about its involvement in the games on its website and social media.

claim: "Mark Zuckerberg, CEO de Meta, ha retirado la verificación” de Nicolás Maduro en Facebook e Instagram.
summary: Captura de pantalla de la página de Facebook de Nicolás Maduro del 1 de abril de 2022 en Archive.today. Captura de pantalla de la página de Instagram de Nicolás Maduro del 13 de noviembre de 2020 en Wayback Machine. Archivos de la cuenta de Instagram de Maduro de 2017, 2019 y 2020, no muestran el sello de verificación.

claim: El 31 de julio de 2024 confirmaron el fallecimiento del expresidente Donald Trump en un accidente de helicóptero.
summary: El expresidente sufrió un intento de asesinato el 13 de julio en un mitin en Butler, Pensilvania, pero Trump dijo que ya se recuperó de una herida de bala en su oreja derecha. Trump tiene programados mítines de campaña en Atlanta, Georgia, el 3 de agosto y en Bozeman, Montana, el 9 de agosto, según su página oficial de campaña. "EL MUNDO DE LUTO… ..FALLECE NUESTRO GRAN #IDOLO..EN ACCIDENTE CONFIRMAN LA NOTICIA EN LA MAÑANA DE HOY..", dice la publicación en Facebook del 31 de julio.

claim: Biden Executive Order 14019 “requires our taxpayer-funded federal agencies to violate the Hatch Act and engage in illegal vote harvesting.”
summary: The order does not require federal agencies to violate the Hatch Act. The order calls on federal agencies to expand voter registration activities and to do so within the bounds of the law. Tenney claimed that Executive Order 14019 "requires our taxpayer-funded federal agencies to violate the Hatch Act and engage in illegal vote harvesting."

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris “was born in Canada.”
summary: (Screengrab from Threads) Harris was born Oct. 20, 1964, in Oakland, California. RELATED: Kamala Harris is again facing attacks on her racial identity. A July 31 Threads post claimed Harris was not American because she "was born in Canada."

claim: Switzerland “no longer recognizes Islam as an official religion.”
summary: The law followed a 2011 referendum in which Swiss voters approved a proposal to ban face coverings in public. In 2021, the Swiss government opposed the referendum to ban face coverings, as did a coalition of left-leaning parties that called the proposal Islamophobic, The Associated Press reported then. We rate claims Switzerland no longer recognizes Islam False.

claim: “Netflix loses 6 million subscribers within hours of donation announcement.”
summary: "Netflix loses 6 million subscribers within hours of donation announcement: ‘The people have spoken,’" text in an image featuring Harris said in a July 26 Facebook post. We found no evidence to support the claim that Netflix has lost 6 million subscribers as a result of Hasting’s donation. But claims that Netflix lost millions of subscribers as a result originated on a self-described satire page.

claim: “Estados Unidos decide INVADIR VENEZUELA”.
summary: Después de la elección presidencial del 28 de julio, el Secretario de Estado de Estados Unidos, Anthony Blinken, expresó preocupación sobre los resultados y pidió la publicación de la tabulación detallada de los votos. (Captura de pantalla de publicación en Facebook) El 30 de julio, el Presidente Joe Biden dijo que habló con el presidente de Brasil sobre asuntos bilaterales y regionales, incluyendo la elección en Venezuela. "Estamos de acuerdo en la necesidad de que las autoridades electorales venezolanas publiquen las cifras de votos completas, transparentes y detalladas, a nivel de los centros de votación.

claim: President Joe Biden “killed his first wife.”
summary: "Yall know Biden killed his first wife and blamed it on a drunk driver and the man hadn’t even been drinking and the police reports have been lost," the July 18 post said. We rate claims that Biden killed his first wife Pants on Fire! Nealia Biden, 30, was driving the family’s station wagon Dec. 18, 1972, when she and Biden’s infant daughter, Naomi, were killed in a collision.

claim: Kamala Harris was “Indian all the way, and then all of a sudden, she made a turn and she went, she became a Black person.”
summary: Trump said Harris was Indian and then "made a turn" and "became a Black person." Harris said she grew up embracing her Indian culture while proudly living as a Black girl. Harris has embraced her Black identity and multicultural background in several ways.

claim: "Donald Trump intends to cut Social Security."
summary: But the Harris campaign ignores most of what Trump has said during the 2024 campaign — namely, that he will not cut Social Security and Medicare. Trump has repeatedly said he would not cut Social Security at campaign rallies in Michigan and Georgia and in multiple posts on his Truth Social platform. "Donald Trump intends to cut Social Security and Medicare," Harris said.

claim: “Even before the pandemic, America went into a manufacturing recession.”
summary: There is no official definition for when an industrial sector enters recession, but by two common metrics — employment and output — U.S. manufacturing was tipping negative starting in early 2019, Trump’s third year in office. In other words, manufacturing output was declining for more than a year — then the pandemic hit. Although manufacturing employment rose robustly for the first two years of Trump’s term, this job growth stalled in his third year and fell slightly before the pandemic hit during his fourth year.

claim: Video shows that “JD Vance endorses Project 2025.”
summary: But the Harris campaign’s claim is inaccurate: This video does not show Vance endorsing Project 2025 — he made these comments in 2021, more than a month before announcing his Senate run and two years before the Project 2025 plan was made public. Vance did not mention nor endorse Project 2025 then. Vance has expressed support from some — but not all — of the ideas Project 2025 promotes.

claim: "Kamala just launched her presidential campaign on RuPaul's Drag Race."
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris launched her presidential campaign soon after President Joe Biden announced July 21 that he would withdraw from the race and endorse Harris’ candidacy. On July 26, Harris appeared on the Season 9 finale of "RuPaul’s Drag Race All Stars," a reality competition show airing on MTV. And on July 23, Harris appeared before a crowd of thousands in Milwaukee.

claim: Says Kamala Harris tweeted, “It’s BLACK LIVES MATTER, not ‘Biden Loves Minors!’”
summary: But Vice President Kamala Harris didn’t post on X reacting to calls to prosecute Cheatle. "I am DISGUSTED by @BoLoudon’s SEXIST call to prosecute our first DEI Secret Service Woman Director," reads what looks like an X post from Harris, referring to a conservative commentator and friend of Trump’s son, Barron. "Bo is a 17 year old RACIST — it’s BLACK LIVES MATTER, not ‘Biden Loves Minors!’ DO NOT follow him!’" A July 28 Instagram post sharing an image of the purported X post was flagged as part of Meta’s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed.

claim: Says Kamala Harris proposed on X that “we have the next debate at a venue Donald Trump feels more comfortable: Jeffrey Epstein’s townhouse.”
summary: So, what Harris did post July 25 about Trump and debating? We rate claims Harris wrote an X post suggesting that she and Trump debate at Epstein’s house False. A supposed X post from Harris that same day appears to show the vice president connecting Trump to the deceased financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris “endorsed free taxpayer-funded government health care for all illegal aliens.”
summary: Harris has not expressly said she supports free, taxpayer-supported health coverage for immigrants who are in the country illegally. Harris signaled in 2019 that her Medicare for All proposal would cover immigrants who are in the country illegally. Republicans have sought to portray Harris as extreme on immigration and assert that  she supports free, taxpayer-funded health benefits for immigrants who are in the country illegally.

claim: Sen. JD Vance is “known for his obsession with couches.”
summary: Pritzker’s claim referred to the false assertion that Vance wrote in his bestselling 2016 book, "Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis," that he had a sexual encounter with a couch. Pritzker’s claim that Vance has an "obsession with couches" is unfounded. NewsGuard, a company that monitors online misinformation, found the claim originated with a satirical X post that said Vance had written about pleasuring himself with a couch.

claim: Este video muestra un robo de votos en la elección del 2024 en Venezuela.
summary: Después de la elección del 28 de julio, el Secretario de Estado de Estados Unidos, Anthony Blinken, quien estaba en Tokio, expresó preocupación de que el resultado de la elección venezolana "no refleje la voluntad o los votos del pueblo venezolano". The New York Times reportó el 28 de julio que "en algunos centros de votación clave, los funcionarios electorales se negaron a entregar los recuentos en papel a los observadores electorales" y que hubo reportes de intimidación de votantes e irregularidades. Las autoridades electorales de Venezuela declararon a Nicolás Maduro el ganador de las elecciones presidenciales del país, pero los candidatos de oposición cuestionan la integridad de los resultados.

claim: Video shows “thousands of Christians in France gathered to pray after Olympics opening mocked Jesus Christ.”
summary: "Breaking: Thousands of Christians in France gathered to pray after Olympics opening mocked Jesus Christ," read text across a video shared in a July 29 Instagram post. Some X users shared a different video and claimed it, too, showed people gathered in Paris for a "worship service" in response to the Olympics opening ceremony. Nevertheless, some social media users shared a video that they claimed showed thousands gathering in France to pray in response.

claim: Project 2025 would end gay marriage.
summary: "The legal recognition of same-sex marriage is not discussed in Project 2025’s Mandate for Leadership," its website says. PolitiFact’s review of Project 2025 found no call to eliminate the right to same-sex marriage. Other posts we saw carried similar doomy messages about gay marriage: Project 2025 will "end marriage equality," "overturn" the right to gay marriage or "ban" gay marriage, they said.

claim: “Netflix stock tumbles almost 40%” after the company donated to Kamala Harris’ campaign.
summary: We rate claims that Netflix’s stock tumbled after the company donated to Harris’ presidential campaign False. Spoiler alert: Netflix’s stock didn’t plummet 40% after the company donated to Vice President Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign, contrary to viral social media posts. But the article and social media posts falsely claim that the donation came from the company, rather than Hastings.

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris is “calling for an end to the child tax credit.”
summary: In January, Harris lauded the House for passing a bipartisan tax package that includes the child tax credit expansion. Vance said Harris is "calling on ending the child tax credit." Harris called the increased child tax credit "one of the most important, one of the most impactful parts of the American Rescue Plan."

claim: Video shows “several masked men stormed a local voting station and stole the ballot boxes” in Venezuela’s 2024 election.
summary: Social media posts claim that a video shows "several masked men stormed a local voting station and stole the ballot boxes" during Venezuela’s 2024 election. Social media posts claim that a video shows people stealing ballot boxes from local election sites. "UNDEMOCRATIC: In Punta Cardón, Falcón State, Venezuela, it is reported that several masked men stormed a local voting station and stole the ballot boxes transporting then to an undisclosed location afterwards," a July 28 X post says, using "then" when it probably meant "them."

claim: Kamala Harris “wants to defund the police.”
summary: We did not find that Harris called for dissolving police departments. The Harris campaign said that she does not support police defunding (as her campaign told us in 2020) and pointed to statements in which she spoke in favor of police funding. Harris did not go that far — she said police were necessary.

claim: “100 million ballots (Democrats) prefilled now have the wrong name.”
summary: (Screenshot from Instagram) Experts told PolitiFact this claim is wrong: There are no official general election ballots yet. "There would be no basis in law for election officials to prepare the ballots for this fall’s general election prior to the deadline for the political parties to identify to those election officials who the party’s nominees are," Edward Foley, Ohio State University law professor, told PolitiFact in a July 26 email. Election law experts say it’s not

claim: "Mike Pence endorsed Kamala Harris.”
summary: We found no evidence that Pence has publicly endorsed Harris for president and a spokesperson for an organization Pence founded said he doesn’t plan to endorse her. Pence has said he will not endorse Trump for president. But some social media posts are claiming that Pence has endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic nominee for president.
